**Guodian Laozi Collation**
**A. Chu Bamboo Slip Version C**
The Great One gives birth to water,
Water in turn assists the Great One, thus forming heaven.
Heaven in turn assists the Great One, thus forming earth.
Heaven and earth 〈mutually assist each other〉, thus forming the numinous luminants.
The numinous luminants mutually assist each other, thus forming yin and yang.
Yin and yang mutually assist each other, thus forming the four seasons.
The four seasons mutually assist each other, thus forming cold and heat.
Cold and heat mutually assist each other, thus forming dampness and dryness.
Dampness and dryness mutually assist each other, ceasing only when the year is complete.
The ancient year is that which dampness and dryness generate.
Dampness and dryness are that which cold and heat generate.
Cold and heat are that which the four seasons generate.
The four seasons are that which yin and yang generate.
Yin and yang are that which the numinous luminants generate.
The numinous luminants are that which heaven generates.
Heaven and earth are that which the Great One generates.
Thus the Great One is concealed in water, moving through the seasons.
Revolving, it may 〈begin anew, and can serve as〉 the mother of the ten thousand things.
It can be deficient, it can be full,
Using constancy to serve as the warp of the ten thousand things.
This is what heaven cannot destroy,
What earth cannot bury,
What yin and yang cannot complete.
The noble person knows this is called the 〈Dao/Way〉.
Below is earth, yet it is called earth.
Above is qi, yet it is called heaven.
The Dao/Way is also its name.
I beg to hear its designation.
Those who act in accordance with the Dao/Way must rely on its name;
When the ancient affairs are accomplished, their persons endure.
The sage’s way of acting also relies on its name;
When the ancient achievements are complete, their persons remain unharmed.
Heaven and earth’s names stand in parallel,
Yet their transformations proceed in different directions, not deliberately corresponding.
〈Heaven is insufficient〉 in the northwest, thus its lower regions are high and strong.
Earth is insufficient in the southeast, thus its upper regions 〈are low and full〉.
What is insufficient above has surplus below;
What is insufficient below has surplus above.
The Dao/Way of heaven values weakness.
The completed bird nourishes the living.
Attack the strong, rest in 〈weakness〉.
In the highest state, those below know it exists.
Some approach it with intimacy and praise,
Some with awe,
Some with denial.
When trust is insufficient, how can there be no mistrust?
How profound is its esteem for speech!
When affairs are accomplished and merits recounted,
The hundred clans say, “We did it naturally.”
When the great Dao/Way is abandoned, how can there be benevolence and righteousness?
When the six relations are in discord, how can there be filial piety and kindness?
When states and households are in chaos, how can there be upright ministers?
Grasp the great image, and the world will come.
Coming without harm, peace and greatness abide.
Music and bait bring travelers to a halt.
Thus the 〈Dao/Way’s words〉 emerge:
Bland, they seem tasteless;
Looked at, they cannot be seen;
Listened to, they cannot be heard.
Yet they cannot be exhausted.
The noble person at home values the left;
In warfare, the right is valued.
Thus it is said: Weapons 〈are inauspicious tools;
Only when unavoidable are they used〉.
Sharpness and stealth are best,
Not to be glorified.
To glorify them is to delight in killing.
Those who delight 〈in killing cannot〉 achieve their will in the world.
Thus in auspicious affairs, the left is primary;
In mourning, the right is primary.
Therefore, the deputy general stands on the left,
The supreme general on the right.
This is to say, they are positioned as in mourning rites.
〈When the slain are many〉, they are arranged with sorrowful mourners.
When victorious in battle, they are positioned as in mourning rites.
Those who act will fail;
Those who grasp will lose.
The sage does nothing, thus does not fail;
Grasps nothing, thus does not lose.
Be cautious at the end as at the beginning,
And there will be no failed affairs.
People’s failures always occur when they are about to succeed.
Thus the sage desires what others do not desire,
Does not value rare goods;
Learns what others do not learn,
Returns to what the multitude has passed by.
Thus they can assist the naturalness of the ten thousand things
Without daring to act.

**B. Chu Bamboo Slip Version B**
In governing people and serving heaven, nothing surpasses frugality.
Only through frugality can one be early,
Thus early in submission.
This is called 〈accumulating virtue repeatedly.
With repeated accumulation of virtue, there is nothing〉 one cannot overcome.
〈Nothing〉 one cannot overcome means none know its limits.
When none know its limits, one can possess the state.
Possessing the state’s mother, one can long 〈endure.
This is called deep roots and firm foundation〉,
The Dao/Way of long life and enduring vision.
Pursuing learning, one daily increases;
Pursuing the Dao/Way, one daily diminishes.
Diminish and further diminish,
Until one reaches non-action.

Non-action and no non-action.
Abandon learning and there is no sorrow.
Between assent and reproach,
How far apart are they?
What people fear,
One cannot but fear.
Glory and disgrace are like a pendant—
Honor great calamity as one’s own body.

What is meant by "glory and disgrace are like a pendant"?
Glory is a lowly thing:
Gained, it is like a pendant;
Lost, it is like a pendant.
This is called "glory and disgrace are like a pendant."

What is meant by "honor great calamity as one’s own body"?
The reason I have great calamity
Is that I have a body.
When I no longer have a body,
What calamity could there be?
Thus, one who values the body for the sake of the world
May be entrusted with the world.
One who cherishes the body for the sake of the world
May be relied upon with the world.

The highest scholar, hearing the Dao/Way,
Diligently practices it.
The middling scholar, hearing the Dao/Way,
Half believes, half doubts.
The lowest scholar, hearing the Dao/Way,
Laughs loudly at it.
If it were not laughed at,
It would not suffice to be the Dao/Way.
Therefore, established sayings have it:
The bright Dao/Way seems obscure;
The advancing Dao/Way seems retreating.
The lofty virtue seems like a valley;
Great purity seems sullied;
Abundant virtue seems insufficient.
Established virtue seems furtive;
True integrity seems fickle.
Great squareness has no corners;
Great vessels are slowly completed;
Great music is scarcely heard.
The celestial image has no form;
The Dao/Way 〈is nameless in its praise〉.

Close the gates,
Seal the openings,
And to the end of life there will be no toil.
Open the openings,
Multiply affairs,
And to the end of life there will be no relief.

Great perfection seems flawed,
Yet its use is unexhausted.
Great fullness seems empty,
Yet its use is inexhaustible.
Great skill seems clumsy;
Great accomplishment seems deficient;
Great uprightness seems bent.

Movement overcomes cold;
Stillness overcomes heat.
Purity and tranquility
Can set the world in order.

What is well established cannot be uprooted;
What is well preserved cannot be lost.
Descendants will continue their sacrifices without end.

Cultivate it in the self,
And its virtue is true.
Cultivate it in the family,
And its virtue overflows.
Cultivate it in the village,
And its virtue endures.
Cultivate it in the state,
And its virtue abounds.
Cultivate it in the world,
And its virtue is vast.
Observe the family through the family;
Observe the village through the village;
Observe the state through the state;
Observe the world through the world.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

From the *A Manuscript of the Chu Bamboo Slips*:

Abandon cunning and discard partiality,
And the people’s benefit will increase a hundredfold.
Abandon artifice and discard profit,
And thieves and bandits will vanish.
Abandon deceit and discard scheming,
And the people will return to filial piety.

These three sayings, as governing principles, are not enough—
Some must be commanded, some must be guided.
Hold to simplicity and preserve uncarved wood,
Lessen selfishness and restrain desire.

The rivers and seas become kings of all valleys
Because they can place themselves below them—
Thus they become kings of all valleys.
The sage stands before the people,
Yet places himself behind them;
Stands above the people,
Yet speaks humbly to them.
When he stands above the people,
They do not feel his weight.
When he stands before the people,
They do not feel harmed.
The world delights in advancing him and never tires.
Because he does not contend,
No one in the world can contend with him.

No crime is graver than excessive desire;
No misfortune is worse than covetousness;
No calamity is greater than discontent.
Knowing contentment as contentment—
This is everlasting contentment.

Those who assist rulers with military force
Do not desire to dominate the world by arms.
Good outcomes are achieved and nothing more—
Not used to seize power.
Achieve and do not boast,
Achieve and do not arrogantly display,
Achieve and do not claim credit—
This is called achieving without dominating,
And such conduct is excellent.

Of old, those who excelled as knights
Were profoundly subtle, deeply penetrating, too profound to be known.
Thus I describe them:
Cautious, as if crossing a winter stream;
Wary, as if fearing neighbors on all sides;
Respectful, as if a guest;
Yielding, as if ice about to melt;
Simple, as if uncarved wood;
Vast, as if a valley;
Turbid, as if muddy water.

Who can make the turbid clear?
It will gradually become clear.
Who can make the still move?
It will gradually come to life.
Those who preserve this Way do not desire fullness.
Because they do not desire fullness,
They can remain hidden and complete renewal.

To act is to fail;
To grasp is to lose.
Therefore the sage does not act and does not fail,
Does not grasp and does not lose.
In managing affairs,
Be as careful at the end as at the beginning—
Then there will be no failure.
The sage desires what others do not desire,
Does not value rare goods;
Learns what others do not learn,
Returns to what the multitude has passed by.
Thus the sage can assist the self-so of the myriad things
Without presuming to act.

The Way is ever without action.
If lords and kings can hold to it,
The myriad things will transform themselves.
Transforming yet desiring to arise,
I would restrain them with nameless simplicity.
Nameless simplicity—
They too will know contentment,
Knowing contentment, they will be at peace,
And the myriad things will settle of themselves.

Act without acting,
Manage without managing,
Taste without tasting.

The great begins in the small;
The high begins at the base.
What is to be felled begins as a sapling;
A nine-tiered terrace rises from heaps of earth;
A journey of a thousand miles begins beneath the feet.

Those who know do not speak;
Those who speak do not know.
Close the gates,
Blunt the edges,
Soften the glare,
Merge with the dust,
File down the projections,
Untangle the knots—
This is called the Mysterious Sameness.

Heaven and earth unite to send down sweet dew,
Which the people, without command, receive equally.
When the system of names first arose,
Names were established.
Once names exist,
One must also know when to stop—
Knowing when to stop prevents peril.

The Way in the world
Is like small streams flowing into rivers and seas.
All things come to completion,
Yet existed before heaven and earth.
Silent, formless,
Standing alone without change,
It can be called the Mother of the world.
I do not know its name—
I style it the Dao.
Forced to name it, I call it Great.
Great means passing on,
Passing on means going far,
Going far means returning.

Heaven is great, earth is great,
The Dao is great, the king is also great.
Within the realm there are four great things,
And the king occupies one of them.
Man models himself on earth,
Earth models itself on heaven,
Heaven models itself on the Dao,
The Dao models itself on the self-so.

Between heaven and earth,
It is like a bellows—
Empty yet inexhaustible,
The more it moves, the more it yields.
To reach emptiness is the constant goal;
To guard centeredness is the firm practice.
The myriad things arise together,
And I observe their return.

All things flourish and return to their root.
Returning to the root is called stillness;
Stillness is called submitting to fate.
Submitting to fate is the constant.
To know the constant is called illumination.

In its stability, it is easily disturbed;
Before signs appear, it is easily planned for;
In its fragility, it is easily broken;
In its subtlety, it is easily scattered.
Act before it exists;
Govern before disorder arises.

A tree as great as a man’s embrace
Begins as a tiny shoot.
A nine-tiered terrace
Rises from heaps of earth.
A height of a hundred fathoms
Begins beneath the feet.

Thus it cannot be made near, nor can it be made distant;
It cannot be made beneficial, nor can it be made harmful;
It cannot be made noble, nor can it be made base.
Therefore, it is honored by all under heaven.

Govern the state with uprightness,
Deploy troops with cunning,
Win the world without action.
How do I know this is so?
The more taboos in the world,
The poorer the people grow.
The more sharp tools the people possess,
The more troubled the state becomes.
The more knowledge people acquire,
The more strange things arise.
The more laws and decrees are promulgated,
The more thieves and bandits appear.

Therefore, the sage declares:
I take no action, and the people enrich themselves;
I remain still, and the people transform of their own accord;
I cherish tranquility, and the people rectify themselves;
I desire not to desire, and the people return to simplicity.

One whose virtue is profound resembles an infant.
Wasps, scorpions, vipers, and snakes do not sting;
Fierce beasts do not seize;
Birds of prey do not strike.
Though bones are weak and sinews soft, the grasp is firm.
Unknowing of the union of male and female, yet the essence is complete—
Such is the perfection of vitality.
Crying all day without hoarseness—
Such is the perfection of harmony.

To know harmony is called constancy;
To know constancy is called illumination.
To augment life is called auspicious;
To let the mind command the qi is called strength.
When things reach their prime, they age—
This is called not following the Dao.

Which is dearer, fame or life?
Which is greater, life or wealth?
Which is more grievous, gain or loss?
Excessive love must lead to great expenditure;
Hoarded wealth must lead to heavy loss.
Know contentment and avoid disgrace;
Know when to stop and avoid danger—
Thus can one endure long.

That which returns is the movement of the Dao;
That which is weak is the function of the Dao.
All things under heaven arise from being,
And being arises from non-being.

Fill it to the brim, and it is better to stop;
Sharpen it to a point, and it cannot be preserved long.
When gold and jade fill the hall, none can guard them.
Wealth and honor breed arrogance,
And leave behind calamity.
Withdraw when the work is done—
This is the Dao of heaven.

[Fragment from the Mawangdui silk manuscript *Laozi* (A text):]
...
Virtue of highest virtue acts without intent;
Highest benevolence acts, yet with intent;
Highest righteousness acts, and with deliberate intent;
Highest propriety acts, and when unanswered, stretches forth the arm to compel.
Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue follows;
When virtue is lost, benevolence follows;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness follows;
When righteousness is lost, propriety follows—
Propriety is the mere husk of loyalty and trust,
And the beginning of disorder.
...
Forethought is the flower of the Dao,
And the beginning of folly.

Thus the great man dwells in its thickness and not in its thinness,
Abides in its substance and not in its flower.
Therefore he discards the husk and takes the kernel.

Of old, those who attained the One:
Heaven attained the One and became clear;
Earth attained □ and became tranquil;
Spirits attained the One and became efficacious;
Valleys attained the One and became full.
Lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for the world.
This is how they attained it.

It is said: If heaven were not clear, it would fear cracking;
If earth were not tranquil, it would fear erupting;
If spirits were not efficacious, they would fear dissipating;
If valleys were not full, they would fear drying;
If lords and kings were not noble and high, they would fear toppling.
Thus what is noble must take the lowly as its root,
What is high must take the low as its foundation.

Therefore lords and kings call themselves "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute"—
Is this not taking the lowly as their root?
Is it not so?
Thus when one seeks many carriages, one ends with none.
Therefore he does not desire to be as jade, but as common stone.

The Dao excels in □□□□□□□.
The movement of the Dao is weakness;
This is the function of the Dao.
Heaven □□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□□.
The center of qi is harmony.

What all under heaven detest are the orphaned, widowed, and destitute,
Yet kings and dukes use these terms to describe themselves.
Things may be diminished yet thereby increased,
Or increased yet thereby diminished.
What others teach, I also teach:
"The violent do not die a natural death."
I take this as the father of my teaching.

Of all things under heaven, none is more yielding than water,
Yet none is stronger in overcoming the hard.
There is nothing that can take its place.
The weak overcomes the strong;
The soft overcomes the hard.
All under heaven know this,
Yet none can practice it.

Thus the sage says:
"One who bears the state’s disgrace is called lord of the altars of soil and grain;
One who bears the state’s misfortunes is called king of all under heaven."
Straight words seem paradoxical.

Victory in cold, stillness in heat—
Only stillness can be the standard for all under heaven.

When the world follows the Dao, swift horses are retired to fertilize fields;
When the world does not follow the Dao, warhorses breed in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than having desires;
No calamity is greater than not knowing contentment;
No fault is greater than the desire for acquisition.
Thus the contentment of knowing contentment is ever content.

Without stepping outside one’s door, one can know all under heaven;
Without looking out the window, one can know the Dao of heaven.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus the sage knows without traveling,
Understands without seeing,
Accomplishes without acting.

To govern all under heaven, one must act without deliberate action.
Those who are not content with this cannot govern all under heaven.

With the heart of all under heaven, one acts for the good:
The good are treated with goodness;
The not-good are also treated with goodness.
This is the power of goodness.
The trustworthy are trusted;
The not-trustworthy are also trusted.
This is the power of trust.

In the world, the sage contracts his heart,
And all the people turn their ears and eyes to him.
The sage treats them all as children.

All people have their faculties—
Ten or three in ten go to their deaths,
Ten or three in ten go to their deaths.
Why is this?
Because they cling to life too tightly.
It is said: Those who are good at preserving life
Do not meet rhinoceroses or tigers on the road,
Nor are they struck by weapons in battle.
The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn,
The tiger has no place to sink its claws,
Weapons have no place to lodge their blades.
Why is this?
Because they have no place of death.

The Dao gives them life;
Virtue nourishes them;
Things shape them;
Circumstances complete them.
Thus the myriad things honor the Dao and value virtue.
The honor of the Dao, the value of virtue—
Nothing commands this, yet it is always so of itself.

The Dao gives them life, nourishes them, rears them, matures them, refines them, nurtures them, and protects them.
It produces but does not possess,
Acts but does not presume,
Leads but does not dominate.

This is called mysterious virtue.
The world has a beginning, which may be considered the mother of the world.
Having attained her, one may know her children;
Having known her children, one returns to guard their mother—
Thus one’s body does not perish to the end.
Block its openings, close its gates,
And to the end of life there will be no toil.
Open its openings, meddle in its affairs,
And to the end of life there will be no rescue.

To see the small is called discernment;
To guard the soft is called strength.
Using its light, one returns to its clarity,
Without leaving the body in peril—
This is called practicing the constant.

When I seem to have knowledge,
I walk the great Dao alone, fearing only to stray.
The great Dao is very level,
Yet the people delight in byways.
The court is very splendid,
Fields are very weedy,
Granaries are very empty.
They wear fine clothes,
Carry sharp swords,
Sate themselves with food and drink,
Possess wealth in abundance—
These are called thieves’ boasts.
Far indeed is this from the Dao!

What is well planted cannot be uprooted;
What is well embraced cannot slip away.
Thus from generation to generation its ancestral sacrifices will never cease.

Cultivate it in the self, and its virtue is genuine;
Cultivate it in the family, and its virtue overflows;
Cultivate it in the village, and its virtue endures;
Cultivate it in the state, and its virtue is abundant;
Cultivate it in the world, and its virtue is universal.
Therefore:
Observe the self through the self;
Observe the family through the family;
Observe the village through the village;
Observe the state through the state;
Observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is so?
By this.

Its richness is like that of an infant:
Poisonous insects do not sting it,
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
Birds of prey do not strike it.
Its bones are weak, its sinews soft,
Yet its grasp is firm.
It does not yet know the union of male and female,
Yet its vital essence is complete—
So perfect is its vitality.
It cries all day without growing hoarse—
So perfect is its harmony.

To know harmony is called the constant;
To know the constant is called clarity.
To enhance life is called auspicious;
For the mind to command the qi is called strength.
When things reach their prime, they grow old—
This is called not following the Dao.
What does not follow the Dao perishes early.

Block its openings, close its gates,
Dull its sharpness,
Untangle its knots,
Soften its glare,
Merge with its dust—
This is called mysterious sameness.
Thus one cannot be drawn near or kept at a distance,
Cannot be benefited or harmed,
Cannot be valued or debased—
Therefore it is honored by the world.

Govern the state with uprightness,
Deploy the army with surprise,
Take the world with non-interference.
How do I know this is so?
By this:
The more taboos in the world,
The poorer the people;
The more sharp tools the people have,
The more troubled the state and family;
The more cunning the people,
The more strange things arise;
The more laws and decrees are promulgated,
The more thieves and bandits appear.
Therefore the sage says:
I do nothing, and the people transform themselves;
I love stillness, and the people right themselves;
I do not meddle, and the people prosper themselves;
I desire not to desire, and the people of themselves become simple as uncarved wood.

When the government is dull and opaque,
The people are pure and simple;
When the government is sharp and intrusive,
The people are lacking and deficient.
Calamity is the support of fortune;
Fortune is the concealment of calamity.
Who knows their ultimate point?
Is there no uprightness?
The upright reverts to the strange,
The good reverts to the ominous—
The delusion of the people has indeed been long.

Therefore the sage is square but not cutting,
Sharp but not piercing,
Straight but not overbearing,
Bright but not dazzling.

To govern a great state is like cooking a small fish.
When the world is governed by the Dao,
Its ghosts do not haunt.
Not that its ghosts are not numinous,
But their numinosity does not harm people;
Not only do their numinosity not harm people,
The sage also does not harm them.
As neither harms the other,
Virtue converges in them.

A great state is the lower reaches of a river—
The female of the world,
The confluence of the world.
The female always overcomes the male by stillness,
And by stillness is the lower.
Thus if a great state places itself below a small one,
It takes the small state;
If a small state places itself below a great one,
It is taken by the great state.
Thus some place themselves below to take,
Some place themselves below and are taken.
A great state desires nothing more than to unite and nurture people;
A small state desires nothing more than to enter and serve people.
Both obtain what they desire,
But the great state must place itself below.

The Dao of heaven benefits and does not harm;
The Dao of the sage acts and does not contend.
The good man is the refuge of the world,
The refuge of the not-good man.

Fine words can win esteem in the marketplace,
Noble conduct can exalt a person.
Yet why do they reject the not-good?
There is reason:
When the Son of Heaven is established and the Three Ministers appointed,
Though one may offer a shared jade disk before a team of four horses,
It is not as good as sitting to present this.
What is the reason the ancients valued this?
Not called seeking, yet one obtains;
Having transgressed, one is thereby exempt.
Thus it is prized by all under heaven.

To act as ruler is to act;
To act is to savor;
Yet whether great or small, many or few,
Repay enmity with virtue.
How can one plan for difficulty?

The difficulties of all under heaven arise from the easy;
The greatness of all under heaven arises from the small.
Therefore the sage never acts greatly,
And so is able to accomplish greatness.

The myriad things must begin with difficulty—
This is why the sage deems difficulty precious,
And thus never encounters difficulty.
What is secure is easy to hold;
What is foreseen is easy to plan;
What is fragile is easy to break;
What is minute is easy to scatter.

Act before things arise;
Order before disorder begins.
A nine-story tower rises from a basket of earth;
A journey of a hundred *ren* begins beneath one’s feet.

Whoever acts fails;
Whoever grasps loses.
Thus the sage does not act, and so does not fail;
Does not grasp, and so does not lose.

The people in their undertakings
Ever near completion yet ruin them—
Thus if one is as cautious at the end as at the beginning,
There will be no failure.

Therefore the sage desires what others do not desire,
And does not prize goods hard to obtain;
Learns what others do not learn,
And returns to what the multitude has passed over.
Thus he aids the myriad things in their natural unfolding,
Yet dares not act.

Hence it is said: those who practice the Way
Do not seek to enlighten the people,
But rather to keep them simple.
The people are difficult to govern
Because of their knowledge.
Therefore to govern the state through knowledge
Is the state’s ruin;
To govern the state through ignorance
Is the state’s blessing.
To constantly know these

Yet none among people can know it,
None can practice it.
Words have their lord, affairs have their master—
Only the Dao knows this.
Thus those who lack this knowledge
Hold me in esteem.

Therefore the sage wears coarse cloth while concealing jade.
To know yet appear not to know is excellence;
Not to know yet appear to know is affliction.
Only by regarding affliction as affliction
Can one be free from affliction.
The sage is free from affliction
Because he regards affliction as affliction—
Thus he is not afflicted.

Do not display what you value,
Nor treasure what sustains you.
Only by not treasuring
Can one be free from harm.

Therefore:
He who dares to act recklessly will perish,
He who dares not act will endure.
Of these two, one brings benefit, the other harm.
The Dao abhors none,
Yet none can fathom its judgment.

The sage does not contend,
Yet none can contend with him.
The saying goes:
"Not speaking, yet responding well;
Not summoning, yet coming of itself;
Unhurried, yet planning well."

How can one govern the people through killing?
If the people always feared death,
Then those who acted perversely
I could seize and kill—
Who would dare?
Yet there is always an executioner.
To kill in place of the executioner
Is like hewing in place of the master carpenter—
Few who hew in place of the master carpenter
Avoid injuring their own hands.

The people’s hunger
Comes from taking too much in taxes.

Thus, the disorder of the hundred clans
Stems from their superiors having something to rely upon.
Thus, the people’s reckless death
Comes from their seeking excessive means to live.
Therefore, those who recklessly treat life as something to be acted upon
Are those who esteem life.
Yet how people live is soft and weak,
How they die is hard and stiff.
So too with the myriad things—plants and trees:
In life, they are soft and supple;
In death, they are brittle and dry.
Hence it is said:
The hard and strong are followers of death,
The soft and weak, the delicate and fine, are followers of life.
Thus, when weapons are strong, they do not prevail;
When trees are strong, they are felled.
The great and strong dwell below,
The soft and weak, the delicate and fine, dwell above.

The Way of Heaven:
It diminishes the excessive
And supplements the deficient.
The Way of man is not so—
It diminishes the deficient
To offer to the excessive.
Who can have abundance
And yet take from Heaven to offer it?
Only one who holds to the Dao.

Thus the sage:
Acts without claiming merit,
Achieves without taking credit.
Is this not because he does not wish to display his worth?

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
Yet nothing can surpass it in overcoming the hard and strong.
By this, none can replace it.
The weak overcomes the strong,
The soft overcomes the hard—
None in the world do not know this,
Yet none can practice it.

Therefore the sage’s words say:
To bear the state’s disgrace
Is called master of the altars of soil and grain;
To bear the state’s misfortune
Is called king of all under Heaven.
True words seem paradoxical.

How can great enmity be reconciled?
It must leave some resentment.
How can this be deemed good?
Thus the sage holds the tally of covenant
Yet does not demand of others.
Those with virtue oversee the tally,
Those without virtue oversee exactions.

The Way of Heaven shows no partiality,
Yet it ever aids the good.

The nameless is the origin of the myriad things;
The named is the mother of the myriad things.
Thus, always without desire,
Observe its subtleties;
Always with desire,
Observe its manifestations.
These two emerge together yet differ in name.
Together they are called the profound.
Profound and more profound,
The gateway to all subtleties.

When all under Heaven know beauty as beauty,
Ugliness arises;
When all know good as good,
Not-good arises.
Thus being and non-being produce each other,
Difficult and easy complete each other,
Long and short shape each other,
High and low fill each other,
Tones and voices harmonize with each other,
Front and back follow each other—
This is ever so.

Therefore the sage abides in non-action,
Conducts affairs without interference,
And teaches without words.
The myriad things arise yet are not turned away,
They are brought forth yet not possessed,
Work is accomplished yet not dwelt upon.
Only because it is not dwelt upon
Does it not depart.

Not exalting the worthy
Prevents contention;
Not prizing rare goods
Prevents theft;
Not displaying what is desirable
Prevents confusion of the people’s hearts.
Thus the sage’s governance:
Empties their minds,
Fills their bellies,
Weakens their wills,
Strengthens their bones—
Ever keeps the people without knowledge, without desire.
Makes those with knowledge not dare to act.
Acting without interference,
There is nothing left undone.

The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao;
The name that can be named is not the eternal name.
The nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
The named is the mother of the myriad things.
Thus, always without desire,
Observe its mysteries;
Always with desire,
Observe its manifestations.
These two emerge together yet differ in name.
Together they are called the profound.
Profound and more profound,
The gateway to all mysteries.

Heaven and Earth are not humane,
They treat the myriad things as straw dogs;
The sage is not humane,
He treats the hundred clans as straw dogs.
The space between Heaven and Earth—
Is it not like a bellows?
Empty yet inexhaustible,
Moving and ever more issuing forth.
Much speech leads to exhaustion;
Better to abide in the center.

The spirit of the valley never dies—
This is called the mysterious female.
The gateway of the mysterious female—
This is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
Subtle yet ever-present,
Its use is inexhaustible.

Heaven is eternal, Earth everlasting.
The reason Heaven and Earth can be eternal and everlasting
Is because they do not live for themselves.
Thus they can long endure.
Therefore the sage puts himself last yet finds himself first,
Sets himself aside yet is preserved.
Is it not because he is without self-interest
That he can achieve his self-interest?

The highest good is like water.
Water benefits the myriad things without contention,
Flowing to places people disdain—
Thus it is near the Dao.
In dwelling, be close to the earth;
In the heart, be deep;
In dealing with others, be kind;
In speech, be sincere;
In governance, be just;
In affairs, be competent;
In action, be timely.
Only by not contending
Can one be free from blame.

Fill it to the brim, and it will spill—
Better not to overfill.
Hone it to a point, and it will soon dull—
One cannot long preserve it.
A hall filled with gold and jade
Cannot be guarded.
Wealth and honor with arrogance
Bring self-inflicted calamity.
Withdraw when the work is done—
This is the Dao of Heaven.

Can you embrace the One and not stray?
Concentrate your qi and attain suppleness—
Can you be like an infant?
Purify your profound vision—
Can you be without flaw?
Love the people and govern the state—
Can you be without cunning?
The gateway of Heaven opens and closes—
Can you play the female?
Understanding all within the four seas—
Can you be without knowledge?
It gives birth and nurtures,
Gives birth yet does not possess,
Acts yet does not rely on,
Leads yet does not dominate—
This is called profound virtue.

Thirty spokes converge at a single hub—
It is the emptiness that makes the wheel useful.
Clay is shaped to form a vessel—
It is the emptiness that makes the vessel useful.
Doors and windows are cut to form a room—
It is the emptiness that makes the room useful.
Thus, what is present provides the benefit,
What is absent provides the use.

The five colors blind the eyes;
The five tones deafen the ears;
The five flavors dull the palate;
Racing and hunting madden the mind;
Rare goods ensnare a person’s conduct.
Thus the sage’s governance:
For the belly, not for the eyes—
Therefore he discards the latter and takes the former.

This fears disgrace as if startled, values great misfortune as if it were the body—what is called fearing disgrace as if startled? What is called valuing great misfortune as if it were the body? My having great misfortune is because I have a body; when I have no body, what misfortune could there be? Thus, one who values the body for the sake of the world may be entrusted with the world; one who cherishes the body for the sake of the world may be given the world.

Look at it yet do not see—call it the Subtle;
Listen to it yet do not hear—call it the Rare;
Grasp it yet do not obtain—call it the Minute.
These three cannot be fully fathomed,
Thus they merge into one.
Its rising brings no light,
Its sinking brings no darkness,
Unceasing, unnameable,
It returns to nothingness—
This is called the form of the formless,
The image of nothingness.
This is called the indistinct and shadowy.
Follow it yet do not see its back,
Grasp it yet do not see its front.
Hold to the Dao of the present to master what is present,
To know the ancient beginning—
This is called the thread of the Dao.

Profound, unfathomable!
Only because it is unfathomable,
I forcefully describe its appearance:
Hesitant, as if crossing a winter stream;
Cautious, as if fearing neighbors on all sides;
Reserved, as if a guest;
Dispersing, as if melting ice;
Simple, as if uncarved wood;
Vast, as if a valley;
Turbid, as if muddy water.
Who can still the turbid and gradually clarify it?
Who can stir the still and gradually bring it to life?
One who preserves this Dao does not desire fullness—
Only because of not desiring fullness,
Can one remain unspoiled and complete.

All things arise side by side,
I thereby observe their return.
All things flourish,
Each returns to its root—
This is called returning to destiny,
Returning to destiny is constancy.
Knowing constancy is enlightenment;
Not knowing constancy leads to recklessness and disaster.
Knowing constancy is all-embracing;
All-embracing is impartial;
Impartial is kingly;
Kingly is heavenly;
Heavenly is the Dao;
Dao is enduring—
One’s body may perish, but one does not.

The highest rulers—people know they exist;
The next—people love and praise them;
The next—people fear them;
The lowest—people despise them.
If trust is insufficient, there will be distrust.
How careful they are with their words!
When tasks are accomplished and affairs completed,
The people all say, “We are naturally so.”
When the great Dao declines, benevolence and righteousness arise;
When wisdom and cunning emerge, great hypocrisy follows;
When the six relations are disharmonious, filial piety and kindness appear;
When the state is in chaos, loyal ministers emerge.
Cut off sagacity, abandon knowledge—people will benefit a hundredfold;
Cut off benevolence, abandon righteousness—people will return to filial piety and kindness;
Cut off skill, abandon profit—thieves and robbers will disappear.
These three sayings, as cultural refinements, are insufficient,
Thus let them have something to which they belong:
Manifest plainness, embrace simplicity,
Reduce self-interest, diminish desires.

What is the difference between approval and disdain?
What is the difference between good and evil?
What others fear, I too must fear—
How boundless this seems!
The people all rejoice,
As if feasting at a great sacrifice,
As if ascending a tower in spring.
I alone remain unmoved,
Like an infant who has not yet smiled,
Weary, as if with no place to return.
The people all have more than enough,
I alone seem lacking.
I have the mind of a fool—how muddled!
The common people are bright,
I alone am dim.
The common people are discerning,
I alone am dull.
Vast, like the sea,
Ceaseless, like the wind,
The people all have purpose,
I alone am stubborn and rustic.
I alone differ from others,
And value being nourished by the Mother.

The power of profound virtue follows only the Dao.
The things of the Dao are indistinct and shadowy—
Shadowy, yet within there are images;
Indistinct, yet within there are forms;
Obscure, yet within there is essence;
Its essence is most real,
Within it there is trust.
From ancient times to the present,
Its name does not depart,
To observe the source of all things.
How do I know the nature of all things?
By this.

One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm;
One who takes long strides cannot walk far;
One who displays himself is not enlightened;
One who justifies himself has no merit;
One who boasts of himself does not endure.
In the Dao, these are called excess food and superfluous action—
Things may despise them.
Thus, one who possesses the Dao does not abide in them.
The crooked will be made whole;
The bent will be straightened;
The hollow will be filled;
The worn will be renewed;
The few will gain;
The many will be confused.
Thus the sage holds to the One and governs the world.
He does not display himself, thus is enlightened;
He does not justify himself, thus has merit;
He does not boast, thus endures;
He does not contend, thus none in the world can contend with him.
The ancient saying, “The crooked will be made whole,”
Is this not true?
Truly, it returns and is preserved.

There is a thing, chaotic yet complete,
Born before heaven and earth.
Silent, formless,
It stands alone and does not change,
It pervades all and does not fail,
It may be considered the Mother of all under heaven.
I do not know its name—
I style it the Dao;
Forced to name it, I call it Great.
Great means it flows ever onward,
Flowing ever onward means it is far-reaching,
Far-reaching means it returns.
Thus the Dao is great,
Heaven is great,
Earth is great,
The king is also great.
Within the realm, there are four greats,
And the king occupies one of them.
Man models himself on earth,
Earth models itself on heaven,
Heaven models itself on the Dao,
The Dao models itself on nature.

The noble person, in daily conduct, does not depart from the weight of the body.
Though there are palaces for pleasure,
How can a ruler of ten thousand chariots be careless with his body in the world?
Carelessness loses the root,
Restlessness loses the ruler.
Good travelers leave no tracks;
Good speakers make no flaws;
Good calculators use no tallies;
Good closers need no bolts, yet none can open;
Good binders need no cords, yet none can untie.
Thus the sage is always good at saving people, and so abandons no one;
Always good at saving things, and so abandons nothing—
This is called inheriting enlightenment.
Thus the good person is the teacher of the not-good;
The not-good person is the resource of the good.
Not to value one’s teacher,
Not to love one’s resource—
Though knowledgeable, this is great delusion.
This is called the essential subtlety.

Know the masculine, hold to the feminine,
Be the valley of the world—
Being the valley of the world,
Constant virtue does not depart,
Return to infancy.
Know the white, hold to the black,
Be the pattern of the world—
Being the pattern of the world,
Constant virtue does not err,
Return to the limitless.
Know honor, hold to disgrace,
Be the valley of the world—
Constant virtue is then complete,
Return to simplicity.
Simplicity scatters and becomes vessels;
The sage uses them and becomes the ruler of officials.
Thus the great system does not cut.

Those who would take the world and act upon it, I see they will not succeed.
The world is a sacred vessel—
It cannot be acted upon.
Those who act upon it ruin it;
Those who grasp it lose it.

Those who act upon it ruin it; those who grasp it lose it.
Things may move or rest, may be warm or cool, may strengthen or weaken.
Thus the sage abandons excess, abandons extravagance, abandons extremity.

Use the Dao to assist the ruler of men—
Do not use weapons to force the world.
Such deeds tend to rebound.
Where armies camp, thorns and brambles grow.
After great wars, years of famine follow.

The skilled commander achieves his aim and stops—
He does not press for dominance.
He achieves his aim but does not boast,
Achieves his aim but does not exult,
Achieves his aim but does not take it as his due.
This is called achieving one’s aim without force.

Things flourish and then age—
This is called not following the Dao.
What does not follow the Dao perishes early.

Weapons are inauspicious tools—
All things may despise them.
Thus those who possess the Dao do not dwell in them.
The noble person values the left in ordinary times,
But in war values the right.
Weapons are not the tools of the noble person—
They are inauspicious tools.
Used only when unavoidable,
Restraint is best—do not glorify them.
To glorify them is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing cannot achieve their will in the world.

Thus in auspicious affairs, the left is honored;
In mourning affairs, the right is honored.
Therefore the deputy general stands on the left,
The supreme general stands on the right—
This is to say they are positioned as in mourning rites.
When many are killed, stand with sorrow and grief.
When victorious in battle, observe mourning rites.

The Dao is ever nameless.
Only when it is cut and carved do names arise.
When names arise, know that it is time to stop.
Knowing when to stop averts danger—
The Dao in the world is like streams and valleys flowing into rivers and seas.

Knowing others is wisdom;
Knowing oneself is clarity.
Overcoming others requires force;
Overcoming oneself is strength.
Those who persist have resolve;
Those who do not lose their place endure.
Those who die yet are not forgotten live long.

The Dao is ever nameless—
It accomplishes its work yet claims no credit.
All things return to it,
Yet it does not act as their master.
Ever without desire,
It may be called small.
All things return to it,
Yet it does not act as their master—
It may be called great.
Thus the sage’s ability to achieve greatness
Lies in not acting great—
Therefore he achieves greatness.

Hold to the great image, and all things will come—
Coming without harm, in peace and great joy.
Music and fine food make the passerby pause.
Thus when the Dao is expressed in words,
It is bland and without flavor.
Looked at, it is not enough to be seen;
Listened to, it is not enough to be heard;
Used, it is not enough to be exhausted.

To listen to it is not enough to hear it;
To use it is not enough to exhaust it.

When you wish to gather it, you must first spread it;
When you wish to weaken it, you must first strengthen it;
When you wish to discard it, you must first grant it;
When you wish to seize it, you must first give it.
This is called subtle illumination.
The weak overcomes the strong.
Fish must not leave the depths;
The state’s sharpest tools must not be shown to others.

The Dao is ever nameless—
If lords and kings can hold to it,
All things will transform themselves.
Transformed yet desiring to take form,
I shall restrain them with nameless simplicity.
Nameless simplicity—
They will no longer be humbled.
By not being humbled, they will return to their true nature,
And heaven and earth will right themselves.

The highest virtue does not act virtuous—thus it possesses virtue.
The lesser virtue does not lose virtue—thus it lacks virtue.
The highest virtue does not act and does not act with intent.
The highest benevolence acts but does not act with intent.
The highest righteousness acts and acts with intent.
The highest ritual acts, yet if none respond,
It waves its arms and drags them along.

Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises;
When virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
When righteousness is lost, ritual arises.
Ritual is the thinning of loyalty and trust,
And the beginning of chaos.
Foreknowledge is the flower of the Dao,
And the beginning of folly.

Therefore the great man dwells in the substantial,
Not in the superficial;
In the fruit, not in the flower.
Thus he discards the latter and takes the former.

Of old, those who attained the One:
Heaven attained the One and became clear;
Earth attained the One and became stable;
The spirits attained the One and became efficacious;
The valleys attained the One and became full;
Lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all.
At their utmost:
If heaven were not clear, it would fear splitting;
If earth were not stable, it would fear crumbling;
If the spirits were not efficacious, they would fear vanishing;
If the valleys were not full, they would fear drying;
If lords and kings were not noble and lofty, they would fear toppling.

Thus, nobility must have lowliness as its root;
Loftiness must have lowness as its foundation.
Therefore lords and kings call themselves "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute"—
Is this not taking lowliness as their root? Is it not?
Thus, the highest renown is no renown.
Do not desire to be lustrous like jade,
But coarse like stone.

The highest Dao—how can it be practiced?
The superior man hears of the Dao and practices it diligently;
The middling man hears of the Dao and wavers between belief and doubt;
The inferior man hears of the Dao and laughs loudly.
If he did not laugh, it would not be the Dao.

Thus the established sayings have it:
The bright Dao seems dim;
The advancing Dao seems retreating;
The level Dao seems uneven;
The highest virtue seems like a valley;
The great purity seems sullied;
The vast virtue seems insufficient;
The established virtue seems frail;
The true substance seems shifting.
The great square has no corners;
The great vessel is late in completion;
The great sound is scarcely heard;
The great image has no form.
The Dao is hidden and nameless.
Only the Dao is good at beginning and good at completion.

The movement of the Dao is return;
The function of the Dao is weakness.
All things under heaven are born of being;
Being is born of non-being.

The Dao gives birth to the One;
The One gives birth to the Two;
The Two gives birth to the Three;
The Three gives birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
Blending their qi to attain harmony.

What people dislike are "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute,"
Yet kings and lords use these to refer to themselves.
Thus, things may be diminished yet thereby increased,
Or increased yet thereby diminished.
What others teach, I also teach:
"The violent do not die a natural death."
I will take this as the father of my teaching.

If the world had the Dao, warhorses would be retired to plow the fields;
If the world lacked the Dao, warhorses would be bred in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than having desires;
No disaster is greater than not knowing contentment;
No fault is greater than desiring gain.
Thus, knowing contentment is ever content.

Without stepping outside, one can know the world;
Without looking out the window, one can see the Dao of heaven.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus the sage knows without traveling,
Names without seeing,
And accomplishes without acting.

The way of learning is to increase daily;
The way of the Dao is to decrease daily.
Decreasing and further decreasing,
Until one reaches non-action.
Through non-action, nothing is left undone.
To take the world, one must always act without acting.
If one acts with sufficient effort,
It is not enough to take the world.

The sage has no constant mind;
He takes the mind of the people as his mind.
Those who are good, I treat as good;
Those who are not good, I also treat as good—
Thus attaining virtue.
Those who are trustworthy, I trust;
Those who are not trustworthy, I also trust—
Thus attaining trust.

The sage in the world is self-effacing,
And all things converge upon him.
The people all fix their gaze upon him,
And the sage regards them as his children.

Life gives birth to death.
The companions of life are thirteen;
The companions of death are thirteen.
People’s lives lead them to the realm of death—
Also thirteen.
Why is this?
Because of the intensity of their striving for life.

I have heard that one who is good at preserving life
Walks through the mountains without avoiding rhinoceros or tiger,
Enters battle without donning armor or weapons.
The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn;
The tiger has no place to sink its claws;
Weapons have no place to pierce their edge.
Why is this?
Because there is no place of death in him.

The Dao gives birth to them;
Virtue nurtures them;
Matter shapes them;
Circumstances complete them.
Thus the myriad things honor the Dao and value virtue.
The honor of the Dao and the value of virtue
Are not conferred but always naturally so.

The Dao gives birth to the One;
The One gives birth to the Two;
The Two gives birth to the Three;
The Three give birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
Blending their qi to attain harmony.
What people dislike are "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute,"
Yet kings and lords use these to refer to themselves.
Thus, things may be diminished yet thereby increased,
Or increased yet thereby diminished.
What others teach, I also teach:
"The violent do not die a natural death."
This I take as the father of my teaching.

The Dao gives birth to them,
Nurtures them, rears them, raises them,
Shelters them, ripens them, sustains them, and returns them—
Yet does not claim lordship over them.
This is called profound virtue.

The world has a beginning,
Which is taken as the mother of the world.
Having attained its mother,
One thereby knows her children.
Having known her children,
One again guards their mother—
And to the end of life suffers no harm.

Block its openings,
Shut its gates,
And to the end of life one will not toil.
Open its openings,
Multiply its affairs,
And to the end of life one will not be saved.

Seeing the small is called clarity;
Guarding the soft is called strength.
Using its light,
Returning to its clarity,
And not bringing misfortune upon oneself—
This is called practicing the constant.

Let me have but little knowledge,
And walk the great Dao,
Fearing only straying from it.
The great Dao is very level,
But the people delight in byways.

The court is very well adorned,
The fields are very weedy,
The granaries are very empty.
They wear fine clothes,
Carry sharp swords,
Sate themselves with food and drink,
And possess wealth in excess—
These are called the boasts of thieves.
This is not the Dao.

What is well established does not uproot;
What is well embraced does not slip away.
Thus, from generation to generation its ancestral sacrifices never cease.

Cultivate it in the self, and its virtue is genuine;
Cultivate it in the family, and its virtue overflows;
Cultivate it in the village, and its virtue endures;
Cultivate it in the state, and its virtue abounds;
Cultivate it in the world, and its virtue is universal.

Therefore,
Observe the self through the self;
Observe the family through the family;
Observe the state through the state;
Observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

One whose virtue is profoundly thick
Is like a newborn babe:
Poisonous insects do not sting it,
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
Birds of prey do not strike it.
Its bones are weak, its sinews soft,
Yet its grip is firm.
It does not yet know the union of male and female,
Yet its organ stirs—
Such is the perfection of its essence.
It howls all day without growing hoarse—
Such is the perfection of its harmony.

Knowing harmony is called the constant;
Knowing the constant is called clarity.
Benefiting life is called auspicious;
The heart directing qi is called strength.
When things reach their prime, they age—
This is called not following the Dao.
What does not follow the Dao perishes early.

Those who know do not speak;
Those who speak do not know.
Block its openings,
Shut its gates,
Blunt its sharpness,
Untie its tangles,
Harmonize its light,
Merge with its dust—
This is called profound union.
Thus, it cannot be made close,
Nor can it be made distant;
It cannot be benefited,
Nor can it be harmed;
It cannot be valued,
Nor can it be demeaned.
Therefore, it is honored by the world.

Govern the state with uprightness,
Deploy the army with surprise,
Take the world with non-interference.
How do I know this is so?
By this:

The more taboos and prohibitions there are in the world,
The poorer the people become;
The more sharp weapons the people possess,
The more troubled the state and clan;
The more cunning and skill the people have,
The more strange things arise;
The more laws and commands are issued,
The more thieves and bandits appear.

Therefore, the sage says:
I do not act, and the people transform themselves;
I delight in tranquility, and the people rectify themselves;
I do not interfere, and the people enrich themselves;
I desire not to desire, and the people simplify themselves.

When its government is unadorned,
The people are simple;
When its government is scrutinizing,
The people are lacking.
Misfortune is that upon which fortune depends;
Fortune is that in which misfortune lurks.
Who knows their ultimate point?
There is no uprightness.
The upright reverts to the strange,
The good reverts to the ominous—
This has long been so.

Thus, square yet not cutting,
All-embracing yet not piercing,
Straight yet not taut,
Luminous yet not dazzling.

In governing people and serving Heaven,
nothing surpasses frugality.
Only through frugality can one be early
to submit—this is called accumulating virtue in abundance.
Accumulating virtue in abundance,
there is nothing one cannot overcome.
When nothing cannot be overcome,
none know its limit.
When one possesses the mother of the state,
one can long endure.
This is called having deep roots and a firm foundation,
the Dao of long life and enduring vision.

Governing a great state is like cooking a small fish.
When the world is established by the Dao,
its ghosts do not possess numinous power.
Not that its ghosts lack numinous power,
but their numinosity does not harm people.
Not only do their spirits not harm people,
the sage also does not harm them.
As neither inflicts harm,
virtue converges and returns.

A great state flows downstream,
the confluence of the world.
The female always overcomes the male through tranquility,
for tranquility is the lower position.
Thus, when a great state humbles itself before a small state,
it gains the allegiance of the small state;
when a small state humbles itself before a great state,
it is embraced by the great state.
Therefore, some humble themselves to gain,
while others, by humbling themselves, are gained.
A great state desires nothing more than to unite and nurture people;
a small state desires nothing more than to enter and serve others.
When both attain what they desire,
the greater should assume the lower position.

The Dao is the reservoir of the myriad things,
the treasure of the good,
the refuge of the not-good.

Fine words can secure esteem,
noble conduct can exalt others.
Yet those who are not good—
how can they be established?

Thus, when enthroning the Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Dukes,
though one may offer jade discs followed by teams of four horses,
it is not equal to sitting and presenting this teaching of old.

Not by seeking does one obtain,
nor by guilt does one escape.
Therefore, it is prized by all under heaven.

What is delicate—
the world’s smallest—
is the world’s easiest to move;
the world’s greatest—
is the world’s hardest to shift.

Thus, the sage does not act,
and so does not fail;
does not grasp,
and so does not lose.

In their undertakings,
the people ever near completion yet ruin them.
Therefore, it is said:
"Be as cautious at the end as at the beginning,
and you will not fail in your affairs."

Thus, the sage desires what others do not desire,
and does not prize rare and hard-to-obtain goods;
learns what others do not learn,
restoring what the multitude has passed over.
Able to assist the self-so of the myriad things,
yet dares not act.

Of old, those who followed the Dao
did not thereby enlighten the people,
but rather made them simple.
The people are hard to govern
because of their knowledge.

Thus, knowledge is the state’s thief,
while unknowing is the state’s virtue.
Ever knowing these two is also a model—
ever knowing this model:
this is called the profound virtue,
deep and far-reaching.
Things return,
and so reach great compliance.

The Jiang and the sea can be kings of the hundred valleys
because they excel at being below them—
thus they can be kings of the hundred valleys.
Therefore, when the sage desires to be above the people,
they must place their words below them;
when they desire to lead the people,
they must place themselves behind them.
Thus, though dwelling above, the people do not find them burdensome;
though dwelling ahead, the people do not find them harmful.
The world all delights in them and does not weary.
Because they do not contend,
no one in the world can contend with them.

Let a small state have few people—
let it have tools for ten or a hundred yet not use them;
let the people value death and not travel far.
Though there be boats and carriages, none ride them;
though there be armor and weapons, none display them.
Let the people return to knotting cords and using them.
Sweet be their food,
beautiful their clothing,
peaceful their customs,
content their dwellings.
Neighboring states may gaze upon one another,
the sounds of their dogs and chickens heard,
yet the people grow old and die without ever visiting one another.

True words are not fine;
fine words are not true.
The knowing are not learned;
the learned are not knowing.
The good are not many;
the many are not good.

The sage accumulates nothing—
having given all to others, they have more;
having bestowed all on others, they have abundance.
Thus, the Dao of Heaven benefits and does not harm;
the Dao of Humankind acts yet does not contend.

The world calls me great,
yet I seem lacking.
It is because I seem lacking that I am great—
had I been full, long since would I have been small.
I ever have three treasures,
which I hold and cherish:
the first is compassion,
the second is frugality,
the third is not daring to be first in the world.
With compassion, one can be brave;
with frugality, one can be expansive;
not daring to be first in the world,
one can become the vessel of leadership.

Now, abandon compassion and yet be brave,
abandon frugality and yet be expansive,
abandon the rear and yet be first—
this is death.
For with compassion, in attack there is victory,
in defense there is solidity.
Heaven will establish one
as if surrounding them with compassion.

Thus, the good warrior is not martial,
the good fighter is not enraged,
the good conqueror does not contend,
the good employer of others places themselves below.
This is called the virtue of non-contention,
this is called employing others,
this is called matching Heaven—
the ultimate of old.

On the use of arms, it is said:
"I dare not be the host but act as guest;
I dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot."
This is called marching without marching,
raising arms without arms,
grasping weapons without weapons,
facing enemies without enemies.
No disaster is greater than underestimating the enemy—
underestimating the enemy nearly costs me my treasures.
Thus, when evenly matched armies meet,
the grieving side prevails.

My words are easy to know,
easy to practice,
yet none in the world can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have a source,
affairs have a lord.
It is only through unknowing
that they do not know me.
Those who know me are few—
thus I am esteemed.
Therefore, the sage wears coarse cloth yet holds jade.

To know yet seem not to know is excellence;
not to know yet think one knows is sickness.
Only by regarding this sickness as sickness
can one be without sickness.
The people’s not fearing
means great fear is coming.

Do not cramp their dwelling,
do not weary their livelihood.
Only by not wearying them
can one avoid weariness.
Thus, the sage knows themselves yet does not display themselves,
loves themselves yet does not prize themselves.
Therefore, they discard the latter and take the former.

Be brave in daring, and you will be killed;
be brave in not daring, and you will live.
Of these two, one brings benefit, one brings harm.
Heaven’s disdain—who knows the reason?
Thus, the Dao of Heaven does not contend yet excels at victory,
does not speak yet excels at response,
is not summoned yet comes of itself,
is at ease yet excels at planning.
Heaven’s net is vast—
wide-meshed yet nothing slips through.

If the people ever cease to fear death,
how can killing be used to threaten them?
If the people ever must fear death,
then those who act perversely—
who can seize and kill them?
If the people ever must fear death,
there is always an executioner.
To kill in place of the executioner
is like hewing in place of the master carpenter—
those who hew in place of the master carpenter
rarely avoid injuring their hands.

The people’s hunger
comes from their rulers’ excessive taxation—
thus they hunger.
The people’s difficulty in being governed
comes from their superiors’ meddling—
thus they are ungovernable.
The people’s disregard for death
comes from their rulers’ excessive pursuit of life—
thus they disregard death.
Only those who do not act for the sake of life
surpass those who prize life.

Of all things in the world,
none is more supple and weak than water,
yet none excels it in overcoming the hard and strong—
nothing can take its place.
The weak overcomes the strong,
the supple overcomes the rigid.
The world knows this,
yet none can practice it.

Thus, the strong and rigid are companions of death,
the supple and weak are companions of life.
Therefore, when arms are strong, they are not victorious;
when trees are strong, they break.
The great and strong dwell below,
the supple and weak dwell above.

The Dao of Heaven is like the drawing of a bow:
the high is pressed down,
the low is raised up.
What has excess is reduced,
what is deficient is supplemented.
The Dao of Humankind is not so—
it reduces the deficient to serve the excessive.
Who can take excess and offer it to the world?
Only one who has the Dao.

Thus, the sage acts yet does not possess,
accomplishes yet does not dwell.
In this way, they do not desire to display their worth.

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing excels it in overcoming the hard and strong—
nothing can replace it.

Thus, the sage’s words declare:
To receive the state’s disgrace is called the master of the altars of soil and grain;
to bear the realm’s misfortune is called the king of all under Heaven.
Straightforward words seem their opposite.

Great [rectitude...]
Acting with goodness—
therefore, the sage holds the left tally and does not demand from others.
Those with virtue oversee the tally;
those without virtue oversee the tax.
[...]

Virtue: three thousand and one.
The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao.
[...]
The name that can be named is not the constant name.
The nameless is the beginning of the ten thousand things;
the named is the mother of the ten thousand things.
Thus, always without desire,
[...]
always with desire—
by these one observes their subtleties.
The two emerge together yet have different names.
Together they are called the profound,
the gateway of the manifold mysteries.

All under Heaven know beauty as beauty—thus, ugliness arises;
all know goodness as goodness—thus, not-goodness arises.
[...]
Being and non-being give rise to one another;
difficult and easy complete one another;
long and short shape one another;
high and low fill one another;
notes and voices harmonize one another;
before and after follow one another—
this is constant.

Therefore, the sage abides in non-action and practices the teaching without words.
The ten thousand things arise yet are not begun;
they act yet are not relied upon;
they accomplish yet do not dwell.
Only because they do not dwell do they not depart.

Not exalting the worthy prevents the people from contending;
not prizing rare goods prevents the people from stealing;
not displaying what is desirable prevents the people’s hearts from being disturbed.
Thus, the sage’s governance:
empties their minds,
fills their bellies,
weakens their ambitions,
strengthens their bones.
Always causes the people to be without knowledge and without desire.
Causes the wise not to dare act—
then there is nothing ungoverned.

The Dao is empty yet its use is inexhaustible.
Profound! It seems the ancestor of the ten thousand things.
Blunts its sharpness,
untangles its knots,
softens its glare,
unites with its dust.
Deep! It seems perhaps to endure.
I do not know whose child it is—
it resembles the ancestor of the gods.

Heaven and earth are not humane;
they treat the ten thousand things as straw dogs.
The sage is not humane;
they treat the hundred clans as straw dogs.
The space between heaven and earth—
is it not like a bellows?
Empty yet inexhaustible,
moving and ever more issuing forth.
Much speech leads to exhaustion—
not as good as guarding the center.

The spirit of the valley does not die—
this is called the mysterious female.
The gateway of the mysterious female—
this is called the root of heaven and earth.
Gossamer-like, it seems to endure;
its use is never exhausted.

Heaven is long, earth is enduring.
Heaven and earth can be long and enduring because they do not live for themselves—
thus, they can long endure.
Therefore, the sage withdraws their person yet their person comes first;
sets their person aside yet their person remains.
Is it not because they are without self-interest?
Thus, they can achieve their self-interest.

The highest good is like water—
water benefits the ten thousand things yet contends not.
It dwells in places all shun—
thus, it is near the Dao.
In dwelling, be good to the earth;
in the heart, be good to the abyss;
in giving, be good to heaven;
in speech, be good to trust;
in governance, be good to order;
in affairs, be good to ability;
in movement, be good to timeliness.
Only by not contending is one without blame.

Thus, to fill it is not as good as stopping.
Hammering it to a point cannot be long preserved.
A hall filled with gold and jade cannot be guarded;
wealth and honor with arrogance bring self-inflicted calamity.
To withdraw when the work is done—
this is the Dao of Heaven.

Carry the vital essence, embrace the One—
can one not depart from it?
Concentrate the qi to attain suppleness—
can one be like an infant?
Purify the profound mirror—
can one be without flaw?
Love the people and govern the state—
can one be without knowledge?
The gates of Heaven open and close—
can one act as the female?
Understanding the four directions—
can one be without knowledge?

It gives life, nurtures,
gives life yet does not possess,
acts yet does not rely,
grows yet does not govern—
this is called the mysterious virtue.

Thirty spokes share one hub—
it is the space within that makes the cart useful.
Clay is shaped to form a vessel—
it is the space within that makes the vessel useful.
Doors and windows are cut to make a room—
it is the space within that makes the room useful.

Thus, the presence of things brings advantage,
while their absence brings utility.
The five colors blind the eyes,
the chase of hunting and racing maddens the heart,
rare treasures distort conduct,
the five flavors dull the palate,
the five tones deafen the ears.

Therefore, the sage governs for the belly, not for the eyes—
thus, he discards the one and embraces the other.
Favor and disgrace are like terror;
regard great calamity as one’s own body.
What does it mean, "favor and disgrace are like terror"?
Favor is base—
gained, it brings terror;
lost, it brings terror.
This is what is meant by "favor and disgrace are like terror."
What does it mean, "regard great calamity as one’s own body"?
The reason I have great calamity
is that I have a body.
When I no longer have a body,
what calamity could there be?
Thus, one who values the body as the world
may be entrusted with the world;
one who loves the body as the world
may be relied upon with the world.

Look at it and it cannot be seen—
it is called the Subtle.
Listen to it and it cannot be heard—
it is called the Rare.
Grasp it and it cannot be held—
it is called the Elusive.
These three cannot be fully fathomed,
thus they merge into the One.
Its rising is not bright,
its sinking is not dark.
Unceasing, unnameable,
it returns to nothingness—
this is called the formless form,
the image of nothingness.
This is called the Vague and Elusive.
Encounter it and you do not see its front,
follow it and you do not see its back.
Hold to the ancient Dao to master present existence,
to know the ancient beginning—
this is called the thread of the Dao.

The ancients who practiced the Dao
were subtle, mysterious, profound, and penetrating—
too deep to be known.
It is only because they cannot be known
that I am forced to describe them:
Hesitant, as if crossing a winter stream;
cautious, as if fearing all around;
solemn, as if a guest;
yielding, as if ice about to melt;
simple, as if uncarved wood;
hollow, as if a valley;
opaque, as if turbid.
Who can still the turbid and gradually clarify it?
Who can rouse the still and gradually bring it to life?
Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness—
only because they do not desire fullness
are they able to remain hidden and not be exhausted.
Attain utmost emptiness,
maintain utter stillness.
The ten thousand things arise together,
and I observe their return.
All things flourish,
each returning to its root—
this is called stillness,
and stillness is called returning to destiny.
Returning to destiny is called constancy.
Knowing constancy is called clarity.
Not knowing constancy leads to recklessness and disaster.
Knowing constancy is all-embracing,
all-embracing is impartial,
impartial is kingly,
kingly is heavenly,
heavenly is the Dao,
the Dao is enduring—
though the body perishes, it is not destroyed.

When the great Dao is abandoned,
then benevolence and righteousness appear.
When wisdom and intelligence emerge,
then great hypocrisy arises.
When the six relations are not in harmony,
then filial piety and kindness appear.
When the state is in chaos and turmoil,
then loyal ministers emerge.
Cut off sagacity, discard knowledge,
and the people will benefit a hundredfold.
Cut off benevolence, discard righteousness,
and the people will return to filial piety and kindness.
Cut off skill, discard profit,
and there will be no thieves or robbers.
These three sayings are not sufficient as teachings—
thus, let them have something to belong to:
Manifest plainness, embrace simplicity,
reduce self-interest, diminish desires.
Cut off learning, and there will be no worries.
How much difference is there between "yes" and "ah"?
How much difference is there between good and evil?
What people fear cannot but be feared—
how vast and endless it is!
The multitude are joyous,
as if partaking in a great feast,
as if ascending a terrace in spring.
I alone am tranquil, showing no sign,
like an infant who has not yet smiled.
Weary, as if with nowhere to return.
The multitude all have more than enough,
while I alone seem lacking.
I have the heart of a fool—
how muddled!
The common people are bright,
while I alone am dim.
The common people are discerning,
while I alone am dull.
Vast, like the sea;
ceaseless, like the wind.
The multitude all have their use,
while I alone am stubborn and rustic.
I alone differ from others
and value being nourished by the Mother.

The power of great virtue follows only the Dao.
The things of the Dao are vague and elusive—
vague and elusive,
yet within them is form;
elusive and vague,
yet within them is substance;
dim and dark,
yet within them is essence.
This essence is most real,
and within it is trust.
From ancient times until now,
its name has never departed,
through which we may see the beginning of all things.
How do I know the beginning of all things?
By this.

Those who stand on tiptoe do not stand firm;
those who take long strides cannot walk far.
Those who display themselves are not enlightened;
those who assert themselves are not distinguished;
those who boast of themselves have no merit;
those who are self-righteous do not endure.
In the Dao, these are called
"excessive food and superfluous conduct"—
things that are detested.
Thus, those who possess the Dao do not abide in them.
To be bent is to be preserved whole;
to be crooked is to be straightened;
to be hollow is to be filled;
to be worn is to be renewed;
to have little is to gain;
to have much is to be confused.
Therefore, the sage embraces the One
and becomes the shepherd of the world.
He does not display himself, thus he is enlightened;
he does not assert himself, thus he is distinguished;
he does not boast, thus he has merit;
he is not self-righteous, thus he endures.
It is only because he does not contend
that no one in the world can contend with him.
The ancient saying, "To be bent is to be preserved whole"—
how could it be empty words?
Truly, to be preserved whole is to return to it.

Gentle winds do not last all morning;
sudden rains do not last all day.
Who is it that makes these?
Heaven and earth.
If even heaven and earth cannot make things last,
how much less can man?
Thus, those who follow the Dao
unite with the Dao;
those who follow virtue unite with virtue;
those who lose it unite with loss.
Those who unite with virtue,
the Dao also unites with them;
those who unite with loss,
the Dao also unites with them.

There is a thing, chaotic yet complete,
born before heaven and earth.
Silent and void,
it stands alone and does not change.
It revolves without endangerment,
and may be considered the mother of heaven and earth.
I do not know its name—
I style it "Dao,"
and forcibly name it "Great."
Great means passing,
passing means far-reaching,
far-reaching means returning.
Thus, the Dao is great,
heaven is great,
earth is great,
and the king is also great.
Within the realm, there are four greats,
and the king occupies one of them.
Man models himself on earth,
earth models itself on heaven,
heaven models itself on the Dao,
and the Dao models itself on nature.

Weight is the root of lightness;
stillness is the ruler of motion.
Thus, the noble person travels all day
without leaving his heavy supplies.
Though he may have splendid lodgings,
he remains tranquil and detached.
How could a ruler of ten thousand chariots
treat his own person lightly before the world?
To be light is to lose the root;
to be hasty is to lose the ruler.

Good traveling leaves no tracks;
good speech leaves no flaws;
good reckoning uses no counting rods;
good closure needs no bolt,
yet cannot be opened;
good knotting needs no rope,
yet cannot be untied.
Thus, the sage is always good at saving people,
and so abandons no one;
always good at saving things,
and so abandons nothing.
This is called following enlightenment.
Thus, the good person is the teacher of the not-good,
and the not-good is the resource of the good.
Not to value one’s teacher,
not to love one’s resource—
though knowledgeable, this is great delusion.
This is called the essential subtlety.

Know the masculine, keep to the feminine,
and be the ravine of the world.
Being the ravine of the world,
constant virtue does not depart,
and one returns to infancy.
Know the white, keep to the black,
and be the pattern of the world.
Being the pattern of the world,
constant virtue does not err,
and one returns to the limitless.
Know the glorious, keep to the humble,
and be the valley of the world.
Being the valley of the world,
constant virtue is sufficient,
and one returns to simplicity.
When simplicity is scattered, it becomes vessels;
the sage uses it and becomes the chief of officials.
Thus, the great system does not cut.
Desiring to take the world,
one must act without action—
for the world is a sacred vessel.

That which cannot be acted upon—
acting upon it brings ruin,
grasping it brings loss.

Things may move or rest, may be warm or cool, may rise or fall.
Thus the sage discards excess, discards extravagance, discards extremes.
The Dao aids the ruler of men,
not by making the world strong through arms.

Where it passes,
thorns and brambles grow.
After great armies come years of famine.
The skilled achieve their aim and stop—
they do not dare to seize by force.
Having achieved their aim, they do not boast;
having achieved their aim, they do not vaunt;
having achieved their aim, they do not claim;
having achieved their aim, they act as if compelled.
This is called achieving one’s aim without force.
Things in their prime grow old—
this is called not following the Dao.
That which does not follow the Dao comes to an early end.

Weapons are inauspicious tools,
