This is called disgrace as if alarmed, valuing great calamity as one’s own body—what is called disgrace as if alarmed?
That which is called disgrace as if alarmed:
to gain it is as if alarmed, to lose it is as if alarmed—
this is called disgrace as if alarmed.
Why is it called valuing great calamity as one’s own body?
The reason I have great calamity is that I have a body;
if I were without a body, what calamity could I have?
Thus, one who values the body as the world may be entrusted with the world;
one who loves the body as the world may be given charge of the world.

Look at it and it cannot be seen—it is called the Subtle;
listen to it and it cannot be heard—it is called the Rare;
grasp it and it cannot be held—it is called the Elusive.
These three cannot be fully fathomed,
so they merge into one.
Its rising brings no light,
its setting brings no darkness.
Endless, unnameable,
it returns to nothingness—
this is called the form of the formless,
the image of nothingness.
This is called the elusive and evanescent,
meeting it, one does not see its head;
following it, one does not see its rear.
Hold to the Dao of the present to master what is present,
and thus know the ancient beginning—
this is called the thread of the Dao.

Of old, those skilled in the Dao were subtly mysterious, profoundly penetrating,
too deep to be known.
It is only because they cannot be known
that I am compelled to describe their appearance:
Hesitant, as if crossing a winter stream;
cautious, as if fearing neighbors on all sides;
respectful, as if a guest;
dissolving, as if ice melting;
simple, as if uncarved wood;
hollow, as if a valley;
opaque, as if turbid.
Who can still the turbid and gradually clarify it?
Who can rouse the still and gradually bring it to life?
Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness.
Only because they do not desire fullness
are they able to be worn yet not newly made.

All things arise side by side,
and I observe their return.
All things flourish in abundance,
each returning to its root—
this is called stillness.
Stillness is called returning to destiny;
returning to destiny is called the constant.
Knowing the constant is called illumination.
Not knowing the constant leads to recklessness and disaster.
Knowing the constant allows for acceptance;
acceptance leads to impartiality;
impartiality leads to kingship;
kingship leads to heaven;
heaven leads to the Dao;
the Dao leads to enduring—
one’s body may perish, but one does not come to great harm.

In highest antiquity, the people knew only that rulers existed;
next, they loved and praised them;
next, they feared them;
next, they despised them.
When trust is insufficient, distrust arises.
How careful they were with their words!
When tasks were accomplished and affairs completed,
the people all said, “We are naturally so.”

When the great Dao declined, benevolence and righteousness arose;
when knowledge and wisdom emerged, great hypocrisy followed;
when the six relations fell into disharmony, filial piety and kindness appeared;
when the state and family fell into chaos, loyal ministers emerged.

Cut off sageness, discard knowledge, and the people will benefit a hundredfold;
cut off benevolence, discard righteousness, and the people will return to filial piety and kindness;
cut off skill, discard profit, and thieves and robbers will disappear.
These three sayings, as teachings, are not sufficient—
therefore, let them have something to which they belong:
manifest plainness, embrace simplicity,
reduce self-interest, diminish desires.
Cut off learning, and there will be no worries.

How far apart are “only this” and “how much more”?
How far apart are beauty and ugliness?
What others fear, one must not fail to fear—
how vast, how endless!
The people all rejoice as if feasting at the Great Sacrifice,
as if ascending the springtime terrace.
I alone remain unmoved, like an infant who has not yet smiled,
weary, as if with nowhere to return.
The people all have more than enough,
while I alone seem bereft.
I have the mind of a fool—how muddled!
The common people are bright,
while I alone am dim.
The common people are discerning,
while I alone am dull.
Boundless, like the sea,
ceaseless, like the ceaseless wind—
the people all have their uses,
while I alone am stubborn and rustic.
I alone differ from others
and value being nourished by the Mother.

The power of the profoundest virtue follows only the Dao.
The things of the Dao are elusive and evanescent—
elusive, evanescent,
yet within them are images;
evanescent, elusive,
yet within them are entities;
profound, obscure,
yet within them is essence.
This essence is most genuine,
and within it is trust.
From ancient times to the present,
its name has never departed,
by which we may observe the origins of all things.
How do I know the nature of these origins?
By this.

That which does not stand on tiptoe is firm;
that which does not peer ahead is bright;
that which does not boast of itself achieves merit;
that which does not praise itself endures.
It is only because it does not contend
that nothing in the world can contend with it.
The ancient saying, “That which is bent will be preserved whole,”
how could it be empty words?
Truly, it will be preserved and return to wholeness.

The Dao gives birth to the One;
the One gives birth to two;
two gives birth to three;
three gives birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
blending their qi to attain harmony.
What people dislike is to be orphaned, widowed, or destitute,
yet kings and lords call themselves by these names.
Thus, things may be diminished yet thereby increased,
or increased yet thereby diminished.
What others teach, I also teach:
“A violent man does not die a natural death.”
I will make this the father of my teaching.

The heavy is the root of the light;
the still is the ruler of the restless.
Thus, the noble person travels all day without leaving the heavy supplies.
Though there may be splendid sights,
they remain calmly detached.
How could a lord of ten thousand chariots
treat his own person lightly in the world?
If he treats it lightly, he loses the root;
if he is restless, he loses the ruler.

A good traveler leaves no tracks;
a good speaker makes no slips;
a good reckoner uses no tallies;
a good closer needs no bolts, yet none can open;
a good binder needs no cords, yet none can loosen.
Thus, the sage is always good at saving people,
and so abandons no one;
always good at saving things,
and so abandons nothing—
this is called inheriting illumination.
Therefore, the good person is the teacher of the not-good;
the not-good is the resource of the good.
Not to value one’s teacher,
not to love one’s resource—
though knowledgeable, this is great delusion.
This is called the essential subtlety.

chunks.translated_text:
He who does not value his teacher,
nor cherish his resource—
though wise, this is called profound delusion.

Know the masculine, hold to the feminine,
to be the world’s stream—
constant virtue never departs,
returning to the state of infancy.

Know the white, hold to the blackened,
to be the world’s model—
constant virtue never errs,
returning to the boundless.

Know the honorable, hold to the humble,
to be the world’s pattern—
constant virtue never fails,
returning to simplicity.
Scattered, it becomes vessels;
the sage employs it as chief and elder.
For great governance requires no carving.

Those who would seize the world and act upon it,
I see they will not succeed.
The world is a sacred vessel,
not something to be acted upon.
Who acts upon it, fails;
who grasps it, loses.

Things may advance or follow,
blow hot or blow cold,
be strong or be weak,
be laden or be empty.
Thus the sage discards excess,
discards extravagance,
discards extravagance.

To guide a ruler with the Dao,
do not dominate the world with force.
Such affairs tend to rebound.
Where armies camp, thorns grow.
After great wars, lean years follow.

The good commander achieves his aim and stops,
not daring to take by force.
He achieves his aim but does not boast,
achieves his aim but does not vaunt,
achieves his aim but does not exult,
achieves his aim only as a last resort.
This is called achieving one’s aim without force.

Things flourish then age—
this is called not following the Dao.
What does not follow the Dao soon ends.

Weapons are ill-omened tools,
loathed by all things.
Thus one who has the Dao does not dwell with them.
The noble person at home honors the left;
in war, honors the right.
Weapons are not the tools of the noble,
they are ill-omened tools,
used only when unavoidable.
It is best to remain tranquil;
do not glorify them.
To glorify them is to delight in killing.
One who delights in killing
cannot achieve his will in the world.

Thus in auspicious affairs, the left is honored;
in mourning, the right is honored.
The lieutenant general stands on the left,
the supreme general on the right—
this means they are positioned as in mourning rites.
When many are killed, one should mourn with sorrow.
When victorious in battle, observe mourning rites.

The Dao is ever nameless.
Though small, none in the world dare subjugate it.
If lords and kings can hold to it,
the ten thousand things will submit of themselves.
Heaven and earth unite to send down sweet dew,
and the people, without command, find harmony.

When the system of names begins,
names arise.
Once names exist,
know when to stop.
Knowing when to stop averts danger.
The Dao in the world
is like streams flowing to rivers and seas.

To know others is wisdom;
to know oneself is illumination.

chunks.translated_text:
Heaven and earth’s myriad things are born from Being;
Being is born from Nonbeing.
The Dao gives birth to the One;
the One gives birth to the Two;
the Two gives birth to the Three;
the Three gives birth to the ten thousand things.
The ten thousand things bear yin and embrace yang,
blending their qi to attain harmony.

What people despise—
being orphaned, widowed, or unworthy—
kings and lords use as their titles.
Thus, some things are diminished yet gain,
while others are increased yet lose.
What people teach,
I too teach:
“A violent man does not die a natural death.”
I will take this as the father of my teaching.

The softest under heaven
gallops through the hardest under heaven.
Nonbeing enters where there is no space.
Thus I know the benefit of nonaction.
Teaching without words,
benefit without action—
few under heaven can attain this.

Which is dearer, name or self?
Which is greater, self or wealth?
Which is more harmful, gain or loss?
Excessive love incurs great cost;
hoarding much invites heavy loss.
Know contentment and avoid disgrace;
know restraint and avoid danger—
thus can one endure long.

Great accomplishment seems incomplete,
yet its use is never exhausted.
Great fullness seems empty,
yet its use is never depleted.
Great straightness seems bent;
great skill seems clumsy;
great eloquence seems inarticulate.
Movement overcomes cold;
stillness overcomes heat.
Purity and tranquility set the world right.

When the world follows the Dao,
warhorses are retired to fertilize fields.
When the world loses the Dao,
mares give birth on the battlefield.
No crime is greater than indulging desire;
no disaster is greater than discontent;
no fault is greater than covetousness.
Thus, knowing contentment’s contentment
is ever content.

Without stepping outside one’s door,
one may know the world.
Without peering through one’s window,
one may know the Dao of heaven.
The farther one goes,
the less one knows.
Therefore the sage knows without traveling,
names without seeing,
completes without acting.

Scholars daily accumulate;
those who hear the Dao daily diminish.
Diminish and further diminish,
until reaching nonaction.
Through nonaction,
nothing is left undone.
To take the world,
one must always act without contrivance.
With contrivance,
one is not fit to take the world.

The sage always takes the heart of the common people as his heart.
Those who are good, I treat as good;
those who are not good, I also treat as good—
thus attaining goodness.
Those who are trustworthy, I trust;
those who are untrustworthy, I also trust—
thus attaining trustworthiness.
The sage in the world
blends his heart with all under heaven.
All people fix their ears and eyes upon him,
and the sage treats them as children.

Birth and death:
thirteen parts belong to life,
thirteen parts belong to death.
Yet people’s lives all lead to death’s realm—
thirteen parts again.
Why is this?
Because they cling to life too tightly.

I have heard that one who skillfully preserves life
walks through the mountains without fearing rhinoceros or tiger,
enters battle without armor or weapons.
The rhinoceros finds no place to gore him;
the tiger finds no place to claw him;
weapons find no place to pierce him.
Why is this?
Because he has no place for death to enter.

The Dao gives birth to them;
virtue nurtures them;
things shape them;
circumstances complete them.
Thus the ten thousand things honor the Dao and value virtue.
The Dao is honored,
virtue is valued—
not by command, but by nature.

The Dao gives birth to them,
nurtures them, rears them,
matures them, ripens them,
sustains them, and protects them.
It gives birth without possessing,
acts without claiming,
leads without dominating—
this is called profound virtue.

The world has a beginning,
which we take as the world’s mother.
Once we know the mother,
we may know her children.
Once we know the children,
we return to guard the mother—
and to the end of life, no harm.
Block the openings,
shut the doors—
and to the end of life, no toil.
Open the openings,
meddle in affairs—
and to the end of life, no rescue.

Seeing the small is called clarity;
guarding the soft is called strength.
Use its light,
return to clarity—
leave no disaster for the self.
This is called following the constant.

If I had the slightest knowledge,
walking the great Dao,
I would fear only straying from it.
The great Dao is smooth,
yet people prefer shortcuts.
The court is immaculate,
the fields are overgrown,
the granaries are empty.
They wear fine robes,
carry sharp swords,
surfeit themselves with food and drink,
possess wealth in excess—
these are the ways of banditry.
This is not the Dao.

What is well planted cannot be uprooted;
what is well embraced cannot slip away.
Thus descendants will continue ancestral sacrifices without end.
Cultivate it in yourself—
your virtue will be genuine.
Cultivate it in your family—
your virtue will overflow.
Cultivate it in your village—
your virtue will endure.
Cultivate it in your state—
your virtue will flourish.
Cultivate it in the world—
your virtue will be universal.

Thus observe the self through the self;
observe the family through the family;
observe the state through the state;
observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is so?
By this.

One whose virtue is profound
is like an infant:
wasps, scorpions, vipers, and snakes do not sting him;
birds of prey and wild beasts do not seize him.
His bones are weak, his sinews soft,
yet his grip is firm.
He does not yet know the union of male and female,
yet his organ stirs—
so full is his essence.
He cries all day without growing hoarse—
so perfect is his harmony.

Knowing harmony is called constancy;
knowing constancy is called clarity.
Excessive vitality is called ill-omen;
the heart forcing qi is called violence.
Things in their prime soon age—
this is called not following the Dao.
Not following the Dao leads to early demise.

Those who know do not speak;
those who speak do not know.
Block the openings,
shut the doors,
blunt the sharpness,
untie the tangles,
soften the glare,
merge with the dust—
this is called mysterious sameness.

Thus one cannot be too close,
nor too distant;
cannot be benefited,
nor harmed;
cannot be valued,
nor despised.
Therefore, it is honored under heaven.

Govern the state with uprightness;
wage war with surprise;
take the world with noncontrivance.
How do I know this is so?
By this:
The more taboos in the world,
the poorer the people.
The more sharp tools the people have,
the more benighted the state.
The more cunning people are,
the more strange things arise.
The more laws are promulgated,
the more thieves and bandits appear.

Therefore the sage says:
I practice nonaction, and the people transform themselves;
I love tranquility, and the people right themselves;
I do not meddle, and the people prosper themselves;
I desire not to desire, and the people return to simplicity.

When the ruler is upright,
the people are simple;
when the ruler is perceptive,
the state is secure.
Good fortune and misfortune
lie in the same place—
who knows their limit?
There is no constancy.
Uprightness reverts to perversity,
goodness reverts to evil.
People’s delusion
has lasted long indeed.

Thus the sage is square but not cutting,
sharp but not piercing,
straight but not overbearing,
bright but not dazzling.

chunks.translated_text:
The upright reverts to the strange,
goodness reverts to the uncanny—
people’s delusion
has endured long indeed.

Thus the sage is square but does not cut,
embraces all but does not pierce,
is straight but not overbearing,
is bright but not dazzling.

In governing people and serving Heaven,
nothing surpasses frugality.
Only through frugality
can one be early in compliance—
this is called accumulating power in abundance.
Accumulating power in abundance,
there is nothing one cannot overcome.
With nothing one cannot overcome,
none can know its limit.
Possessing this, one holds the mother of the state
and may long endure.
This is called the Dao of deep roots and firm foundation,
the Way of long life and enduring vision.

Governing a great state
is like cooking a small fish.
When the Dao is established in the world,
its ghosts do not haunt.
Not that its ghosts lack numinosity,
but their numinosity does not harm people.
Not that their numinosity does not harm people,
but the sage also does not harm them.
As neither harms the other,
their virtues converge and return.

A great state is the lower reaches,
the female of the world,
the confluence of the world.
The female always overcomes the male through tranquility,
and thus is fit to be below.
When a great state humbles itself before a small state,
it wins the small state.
When a small state humbles itself before a great state,
it is embraced by the great state.
Thus, some humble themselves to win,
while others humble themselves and are won.
A great state desires nothing more
than to nurture and shelter people;
a small state desires nothing more
than to enter and serve others.
When both attain their desires,
the greater should humble itself.

The Dao is the lodging of the myriad things.
It is the treasure of the good,
the refuge of the not-good.
Fine words can win esteem,
noble conduct can exalt one above others.
Yet why reject those who are not good?
Thus, when the Son of Heaven is established
and the Three Ministers are appointed,
though one may offer jade discs
followed by teams of four horses,
it is not as good as sitting and presenting this Dao.

Why was this valued of old?
Was it not said:
Through it, one obtains without seeking,
and the guilty are absolved?
Therefore it is treasured by the world.

In acting without action,
in attending without attending,
in tasting without tasting,
whether great or small, many or few,
repay enmity with virtue.
Plan for difficulty while it is easy,
act on the great while it is minute.

I desire not to desire, and the people return to simplicity.

When the ruler is upright,
the people are simple;
when the ruler is perceptive,
the state is secure.
Good fortune and misfortune
lie in the same place—
who knows their limit?
There is no constancy.
Uprightness reverts to perversity,
goodness reverts to evil.
People’s delusion
has lasted long indeed.

Thus the sage is square but not cutting,
sharp but not piercing,
straight but not overbearing,
bright but not dazzling.

chunks.original_text: 亓细也 天下之（难作于）易天下之大（作于细是以圣人冬不为大故能成亓大）夫轻若（必寡）信多易必多难是以人（犹难）之故（冬于难亓安也 易持也 亓未兆也 易谋也 亓脆也 易判也 亓微也 易散也 为之于亓未有也 治之于亓未乱也 合抱之）木生于毫末九成之台作于土百千之高始于足下为之者败之执者失之是以人为（也 故败也 执也 故失也 ）民之从事也 恒于亓成而败之故曰慎冬若始则败事矣 是以人欲不欲而不贵难得之货学不学复众人之所过能辅万物之自然而弗敢为古之为道者非以明（ 民也 将以愚 ）之也 民之难治也
chunks.translated_text:
The minute is where the world’s difficulties arise;
the great is where the world’s vastness begins.
Thus the sage never acts as though great,
and so accomplishes his greatness.

For one who takes things lightly will surely lack trust,
and one who treats much as easy will surely meet much difficulty.
Therefore the sage regards things as difficult,
and so never encounters difficulty.

That which is at peace is easy to hold;
that which shows no sign is easy to plan for;
that which is fragile is easy to break;
that which is subtle is easy to scatter.
Act on it before it comes to be;
order it before it falls into chaos.

A tree of arm-spanning girth grows from a hair-fine sprout;
a nine-tiered terrace rises from a basket of earth;
a journey of a thousand leagues begins beneath one’s feet.
One who acts on it will fail it;
one who grasps it will lose it.
Thus the sage acts not, and so does not fail;
grasps not, and so does not lose.

In their undertakings, the people
constantly fail when nearly complete.
Therefore it is said:
Be as cautious at the end as at the beginning,
and you will not fail in your affairs.

Thus the sage desires what others do not desire,
and does not prize goods hard to obtain;
learns what others do not learn,
restoring what the multitude have passed over,
and so can assist the self-so of the myriad things
without daring to act.

Of old, those who practiced the Way
did not do so to enlighten the people,
but to make them simple.
The people are hard to govern.

chunks.original_text: 以亓知也 故以知＝国＝之贼也 以不知＝国＝之德也 恒知此两者亦稽式也 恒知稽式此胃玄＝德＝深矣 远矣 （与）物反也 乃至大顺江海所以能为百浴（王者以）亓（善）下之也 是以能为百浴王是以人之欲上民也 必以亓言下之亓欲先民也 必以亓身后之故居上而民弗重也 居前而民弗害天下皆乐谁而弗也 不（以）亓争与故天下莫能与争小国寡民使有十百人器而勿用使民重死而远徙又周车所乘之有甲兵所陈之使民复结绳而用之甘亓食美亓服乐亓俗安亓居国相望鸡犬之（声相）闻民至老死不相往来信言不美＝言不信知者不博＝者不知善者不多＝者不善人积既以为人已俞有既以予人矣 已俞多故天之道利而不害人之道为而弗争天下（皆）胃我大＝而不宵夫不宵故能大若宵久矣 亓细也 夫我恒有三市而之一曰兹二曰检三曰不敢为天下先夫慈故能勇检敢能广不敢为天下先故能为成器长（今）舍亓兹且勇舍亓检且广舍亓后且先则死矣 夫兹以单则以守则固天将建之如以兹垣之故善为士者不武善单者不怒善敌者弗与善用人者为之下是胃不争（之）德是胃用人是胃肥天古之极也 用兵又言曰吾不敢为主而为客不敢进寸而退尺是胃行行襄臂执兵乃敌祸莫大于＝适＝近○亡吾矣 故抗兵相若则依者（矣 ）吾言易知也 易行也
chunks.translated_text:
With their knowing,
they thus make knowledge the state’s thief.
With their not-knowing,
they thus make the state’s virtue.
Ever knowing these two,
one may also take them as a model.
Ever knowing the model—
this is called profound virtue,
deep and far-reaching,
returning with things to the Great Compliance.

Thus the rivers and seas
can be kings of the hundred valleys
because they excel at lying low.
Therefore they can be kings of the hundred valleys.

Thus the sage,
wishing to be above the people,
must speak as though below them;
wishing to lead the people,
must place himself behind them.
Therefore he dwells above,
yet the people do not find him burdensome;
he dwells ahead,
yet the people do not find him harmful.
The world all delights in him,
yet does not tire of him.
Because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him.

Let a small state have few people,
equipping them with tools for ten or a hundred,
yet not putting them to use.
Let the people value death
and not wander far.
Though there be boats and carriages,
none ride them;
though there be armor and weapons,
none display them.
Let the people return to knotting cords for use.
Let them find sweetness in their food,
beauty in their clothing,
joy in their customs,
peace in their dwellings.
Neighboring states may be within sight,
the sounds of their cocks and dogs may be heard,
yet the people will grow old and die
without ever visiting one another.

True words are not fine;
fine words are not true.
The knowing are not learned;
the learned are not knowing.
The good are not many;
the many are not good.

The sage accumulates nothing.
Having fully given to others,
he has all the more.
Having fully bestowed upon others,
he has all the more.

Thus the Dao of Heaven
benefits and does not harm.
The Dao of Man
acts and does not contend.

The world all calls me great,
yet I seem unrefined.
It is because I am unrefined
that I can be great.
Were I refined, I would long since have been small.

Now, I ever possess three treasures,
and hold fast to them:
the first is called compassion;
the second is called frugality;
the third is called not daring to be first in the world.

With compassion, one can be brave;
with frugality, one can be expansive;
not daring to be first in the world,
one can become the vessel of completion and leadership.

Now, to abandon compassion and yet be brave,
to abandon frugality and yet be expansive,
to abandon the rear and yet be first—
this is death.

For with compassion,
one can attack and conquer,
defend and hold firm.
Heaven will establish one
as though surrounded by a wall of compassion.

Thus one who excels as a warrior is not martial;
one who excels in battle is not enraged;
one who excels in conquering the enemy does not engage;
one who excels in employing others acts as their subordinate.
This is called the virtue of non-contention;
this is called employing others;
this is called matching Heaven—
the ultimate of antiquity.

On the use of arms, it is further said:
I dare not be the host, but act as the guest;
I dare not advance an inch, but retreat a foot.
This is called marching without marching,
rolling up sleeves without baring arms,
wielding weapons without weapons,
confronting enemies without enemies.
No misfortune is greater than underestimating the enemy—
to do so nearly destroys my treasures.
Thus when evenly matched armies meet,
the grieving side prevails.

My words are easy to know,
easy to practice.

chunks.translated_text:
Yet the world knows not these words,
nor can it practice them.
For speech has its lineage, affairs their lord—
only the unknowing fail to grasp this.
Thus those who do not know me are few,
and I am thereby esteemed.
Hence the sage wears coarse cloth while concealing jade.

To know yet seem not to know is excellence;
not to know yet claim to know is affliction.
Only by recognizing this affliction as affliction
can one avoid affliction.
The people’s failure to fear
portends the advent of great fear.
Do not constrict their dwelling,
nor stifle their livelihood.
Only by not stifling do they remain unstifled.
Thus the sage knows himself yet does not display himself,
loves himself yet does not exalt himself.

Therefore: discard the exhausted, adopt the new.
To be bold in daring is to court death;
to be bold in restraint is to preserve life.
Of these two, one brings benefit, the other harm—
who can fathom Heaven’s aversion?
Thus the Dao of Heaven:
contends not, yet excels in victory;
speaks not, yet responds with perfection;
summons not, yet comes of itself;
acts leisurely, yet plans with excellence.
The net of Heaven is vast, its mesh wide—
though sparse, nothing slips through.

If the people constantly disregard death,
how can they be threatened with execution?
If the people constantly feared death,
and I seized and executed those who transgressed,
who would dare to act thus?
If the people constantly feared death,
there would always be an executioner.
To kill in place of the executioner
is to hew in place of the master carpenter—
those who hew in place of the master carpenter
rarely escape injury to their hands.

The people’s hunger
arises from their rulers’ excessive taxation—
hence their hunger.
The people’s difficulty in being governed
arises from their rulers’ meddling—
hence their unruliness.
The people’s disregard for death
arises from their rulers’ pursuit of lavish living—
hence their disregard for death.
Only those who do not strive to preserve life
are wiser than those who overvalue life.

Man in life is supple and weak,
in death stiff and strong.
All things—plants and trees—
in life are supple and tender,
in death withered and dry.
Thus it is said:
the stiff and strong are companions of death,
the supple and weak companions of life.
Therefore:
when weapons are strong, they do not prevail;
when trees are strong, they break.
The strong and great dwell below,
the supple and weak dwell above.

The Dao of Heaven is like the drawing of a bow:
the high is pressed down, the low raised up;
the excessive is reduced, the deficient replenished.
The Dao of Heaven reduces the excessive
to augment the deficient.
The way of man is otherwise:
it reduces the deficient
to offer to the excessive.
Who can take from the excessive
to offer to Heaven?
Only one who possesses the Dao.

Thus the sage acts yet does not possess,
accomplishes yet does not dwell in it.
In this way he does not wish to display his worth.

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the hard and strong—
for nothing can replace it.
That the weak overcomes the strong,
the soft overcomes the hard,
the world knows yet cannot practice.

chunks.original_text: 故人之言曰受国之是胃社稷之主受邦之不祥是胃天下之王正言若反禾大（怨必有余怨焉 可以）为善是以人执左芥而不以责于故又德司芥德司（夫天道亲恒与善人） 德 三千一 道可道也 （ 非恒道也 名可名也 非 ）恒名也 名万物之始也 有名万物之母也 故恒欲也 （ 以观其眇 ）恒又欲也 以观亓所两者同出名同胃玄之又玄众眇之门天下皆知美之为美亚已皆知善斯不善矣 （ 有之相 ）生也 难易之相成也 长短之相刑也 高下之相盈也 音声之相和也 先后之相隋也 恒也 是以人居为之事行不言之教万物昔而弗始为而弗侍也 成功而弗居也 夫唯弗居是以弗去不上贤使民不争不贵难得之货使民不为盗不见可欲使民心不是以人之治也 虚亓心实亓腹弱亓志强亓骨恒使民知欲也 使夫知不敢弗为而已则不治矣 道而用之有弗盈也 渊呵万物之宗锉亓兑解亓芬和亓光同亓湛呵或存吾不知亓谁子也 象帝之先天地不仁以万物为刍狗人不仁（以）百姓为刍狗天地之亓犹橐舆虚而不而俞出多闻数穷不若守于中浴神不死是胃玄＝牝＝之门是胃天地之根＝呵亓若存用之不堇天长地久天地所以能长且久者以亓不自生也 故能长生是以人退其身而身先外亓身而身存不以亓私舆故能成其私上善如水＝善利万物而有争居众之所亚故几于道矣 居善地心善渊予善天言善信正善治事善能动善时夫唯不争故尤而盈之不若亓已而允之不可长葆也 金玉（盈）室莫之能守也 贵富而自遗咎也 功遂身退天之道也 戴营抱一能毋离乎 气至柔能婴儿乎 除玄监能毋疵乎 爱民栝国能毋以知乎 天门启阖能为雌乎 明白四达能毋以知乎 生之畜之生而弗有长而弗宰也 是胃玄德卅同一毂当亓有车之用也 埴而为器当亓有埴器之用也 凿户牖当亓有室之用也
chunks.translated_text:
Thus the sage’s words declare:
To receive the state’s disgrace is called the lord of the altars of soil and grain;
to bear the realm’s misfortune is called the king of all under Heaven.
Straight words seem their reverse.

Great enmity must leave some resentment—
how can this be deemed good?
Therefore the sage holds the left tally
yet does not demand from others.
Those with virtue oversee the tally;
those without virtue oversee the levy.

The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality,
yet it is ever with the good.

The virtue of the Three and the One:
The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao;
the name that can be named is not the constant name.
The nameless is the beginning of the ten thousand things;
the named is the mother of the ten thousand things.
Thus, constantly without desire,
one observes its subtleties;
constantly with desire,
one observes its manifestations.
These two emerge together yet differ in name.
Together they are called the profound,
the profound within the profound,
the gate of all subtleties.

All under Heaven know beauty as beauty—
thus ugliness arises;
all know good as good—
thus not-good arises.
Being and non-being give birth to one another;
difficult and easy complete one another;
long and short shape one another;
high and low fill one another;
notes and voices harmonize with one another;
before and after follow one another—
this is constant.

Therefore the sage abides in non-action,
practices the teaching without words,
lets the ten thousand things arise without initiating,
acts without depending,
accomplishes without dwelling.
Only because he does not dwell
does it not leave him.

Do not exalt the worthy, and the people will not contend;
do not value rare goods, and the people will not steal;
do not display what is desirable, and the people’s hearts will not be disturbed.
Thus the sage’s governance:
empties their minds,
fills their bellies,
weakens their ambitions,
strengthens their bones.
Ever causes the people to be without knowledge and without desire.
Causes the wise not to dare act—
and where none act,
there is nothing left ungoverned.

The Dao is empty yet in use never fills.
Abysmal, it seems the ancestor of the ten thousand things.
Blunts its sharpness,
untangles its knots,
softens its glare,
merges with its dust.
Deep, it seems perhaps to exist.
I know not whose child it is—
it seems the image before the Lord.

Heaven and earth are not humane:
they treat the ten thousand things as straw dogs.
The sage is not humane:
he treats the hundred clans as straw dogs.

The space between heaven and earth—
is it not like a bellows?
Empty yet inexhaustible,
the more it moves, the more it produces.
Much speech leads to exhaustion—
better to guard the center.

Nourishing the spirit without death:
this is called the mysterious female.
The gate of the mysterious female
is called the root of heaven and earth.
Gently it seems to endure,
in use never exhausted.

Heaven is eternal, earth enduring.
Heaven and earth can be eternal and enduring
because they do not live for themselves—
thus they can long endure.
Therefore the sage withdraws his person yet his person comes first,
puts his person outside yet his person remains.
Is it not because he is without self-interest
that he can fulfill his self-interest?

The highest good is like water:
water benefits the ten thousand things yet contends not,
dwells in places all disdain—
thus it is near the Dao.

In dwelling, be close to the earth;
in heart, be deep as an abyss;
in giving, be like heaven;
in speech, be truthful;
in governance, be orderly;
in affairs, be capable;
in action, be timely.
Only by not contending
is one free from blame.

Fill it to
chunks.overlap_context:
the deficient
to offer to the excessive.
Who can take from the excessive
to offer to Heaven?
Only one who possesses the Dao.

Thus the sage acts yet does not possess,
accomplishes yet does not dwell in it.
In this way he does not wish to display his worth.

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the hard and strong—
for nothing can replace it.
That the weak overcomes the strong,
the soft overcomes the hard,
the world knows yet cannot practice.

Thus, having is for benefit,
not-having is for use.
The five colors blind the eyes,
the chase of hunting and racing madden the heart,
rare goods distort conduct,
the five flavors dull the palate,
the five tones deafen the ears.

Therefore, the sage’s governance
is for the belly, not the eyes—
thus he rejects that and takes this.
Honor and disgrace are like terror:
value great trouble as you do the body.
What does it mean, "honor and disgrace are like terror"?
Honor is inferior—
gained like terror, lost like terror.
This is what is meant by "honor and disgrace are like terror."
What does it mean, "value great trouble as you do the body"?
The reason I have great trouble
is that I have a body.
When I no longer have a body,
what trouble could I have?
Thus, one who values the body as the world
may be entrusted with the world;
one who loves the body as the world
may be relied upon with the world.

Look at it yet do not see—
call it "subtle."
Listen to it yet do not hear—
call it "rare."
Grasp it yet do not obtain—
call it "elusive."
These three cannot be fully reckoned,
thus they merge into one.
Its rising is not bright,
its falling is not dark.
Unceasing, unnameable,
it returns to nothingness—
this is called the form of the formless,
the image of nothingness,
this is called the indistinct and vague.
Encounter it yet do not see its front,
follow it yet do not see its back.
Hold to the ancient Dao
to master present being,
to know the ancient beginning—
this is called the thread of the Dao.

The ancients who were good at the Dao
were subtly mysterious, profoundly penetrating,
too deep to be known.
It is only because they cannot be known
that I am forced to describe them:
Hesitant, as if crossing a winter stream;
cautious, as if fearing all around;
solemn, as if a guest;
dissolving, as if ice melting;
simple, as if uncarved wood;
hollow, as if a valley;
opaque, as if muddy.
Who can still the muddy and gradually clarify it?
Who can rouse the still and gradually bring it to life?
Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness—
thus they can wear out without being made new.

To the utmost emptiness, hold fast to stillness.
The ten thousand things arise together,
and I observe their return.
Things flourish abundantly,
each returning to its root—
this is called stillness.
Stillness is called returning to destiny,
returning to destiny is called constancy.
Knowing constancy is called clarity.
Not knowing constancy leads to recklessness and disaster.
Knowing constancy is acceptance,
acceptance is impartiality,
impartiality is kingship,
kingship is heaven,
heaven is the Dao,
the Dao is enduring—
though the body perishes, it is not imperiled.

The highest rulers are known, yet below them,
some are praised, some feared, some despised.
Where trust is insufficient, there is lack of trust.
How careful they are with their words!
When tasks are accomplished and affairs settled,
the people say, "We did it naturally."
When the great Dao declines, benevolence and righteousness arise;
when wisdom and cunning emerge, great hypocrisy follows;
when the six relations are disharmonious, filial piety and kindness appear;
when the state is in chaos, loyal ministers emerge.

Cut off sageness, discard wisdom, and the people benefit a hundredfold;
cut off benevolence, discard righteousness, and the people return to filial piety;
cut off skill, discard profit, and thieves and robbers disappear.
These three sayings, as mere patterns, are insufficient—
thus let them have something to belong to:
see the plain, embrace the uncarved,
lessen self-interest, diminish desire.
Cut off learning, and there is no worry.
How much difference is there between "yes" and "ah"?
How much difference between good and bad?
What people fear cannot but be feared—
how boundless this seems, not yet at its end!
The crowd is joyous,
as if partaking in the great sacrifice,
as if ascending the springtime terrace.
I alone am unmoved,
like an infant who has not yet smiled,
forlorn, as if with nowhere to return.
The crowd all has more than enough,
I alone seem lacking.
I have the heart of a fool—
how muddled!

chunks.translated_text:
The Way cannot be acted upon—
those who act upon it ruin it,
those who grasp it lose it.
Things may advance or follow,
be hot or cold,
descend or ascend.
Thus the sage discards excess,
discards extravagance,
discards extremity.
With the Dao he assists the lord of men,
not using arms to overpower the world.
His affairs return to him—
where the army has dwelt,
thorns and brambles grow.
Good outcomes are merely sufficient;
do not use them to seize strength.
Be sufficient yet do not boast,
be sufficient yet do not vaunt,
be sufficient yet do not claim attainment.
This is called being sufficient yet strong.
Things flourish then age—
this is called not-Dao.
Not-Dao comes early to its end.

Arms are instruments of ill omen—
things may shun them,
thus the man of desire does not dwell in them.
The gentleman dwells in the left,
but in using arms, honors the right.
Thus arms are not the gentleman’s instruments.
Arms are instruments of ill omen—
only when unavoidable are they used,
and tranquility is prized.
Do not glorify them;
to glorify them is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing
cannot achieve their will in the world.

Thus in auspicious affairs, the left is honored;
in mourning rites, the right is honored.
Therefore the deputy general stands on the left,
while the supreme general stands on the right—
this means they are positioned as in mourning rites.
When many are killed,
one should grieve and mourn them.
Victory in battle
is treated with mourning rites.

The Dao is ever nameless and uncarved—
only small, yet none in the world dare make it a subject.
If lords and kings could hold to it,
the myriad things would of themselves submit.
Heaven and earth unite to send down sweet dew,
and the people, without command, of themselves find balance.

When the system begins, names arise—
once names exist, one should also know when to stop.
Knowing when to stop is how to avoid peril.
The Dao’s presence in the world
is like streams and valleys flowing to rivers and seas.
Knowing others is wisdom.

chunks.original_text: 自知者明也 人者有力也 自者强也 知足者富也 强行者有志也 不失亓所者久也 死而不忘者寿也 道呵亓可左右也 成功遂（事而）弗名有也 万物归焉 而弗为主则恒欲也 可名于小万物归焉 而弗为主可命于大是以人之能成大也 以亓不为大也 故能成大执大象天下往＝而不害安平大乐与（饵）过格止故道之出言也 曰淡呵其味也 视之不足见也 听之不足闻也 用之不可既也 将欲之必古张之将欲弱之必古○强之将欲去之必古与之将欲夺之必古予○是胃微明柔弱强鱼不可说于渊国利器不可以示人道恒名侯王若能守之万物将自化＝而欲作吾将阗＝之＝以＝＝名＝之＝朴＝夫将不＝辱＝以天地将自正 道 二千四百廿六 帛书老子校正
chunks.translated_text:
The one who knows oneself is enlightened.
The one who conquers others possesses strength.
The one who conquers oneself is mighty.
The one who knows contentment is rich.
The one who acts with perseverance has resolve.
The one who does not lose their place endures.
The one who dies yet is not forgotten lives long.

The Dao flows—ah, it may be grasped to left or right.
It accomplishes and completes affairs yet claims no possession.
The myriad things return to it,
yet it does not act as their master—
thus it is ever without desire.
It may be named as small,
yet the myriad things return to it,
and it does not act as their master—
it may be called great.
Therefore the sage’s ability to achieve greatness
lies in not asserting greatness,
and so achieves greatness.

Hold to the great image, and the world will come—
coming without harm, secure, peaceful, and greatly at ease.
Music and fine food may pass the traveler by,
yet the Dao’s words, when uttered, are:
bland—ah, their flavor is plain.
Looked at, they are not enough to be seen.
Listened to, they are not enough to be heard.
Used, they cannot be exhausted.

When you wish to contract something, you must first expand it.
When you wish to weaken something, you must first strengthen it.
When you wish to discard something, you must first elevate it.
When you wish to seize something, you must first give it.
This is called subtle illumination:
the soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.
Fish must not be removed from the depths.
A state’s sharpest instruments must not be displayed.

The Dao is ever nameless.
If lords and kings could hold to it,
the myriad things would transform of themselves.
Should desire arise,
I shall press it down
with the uncarved block of nameless simplicity.
The uncarved block of nameless simplicity
will not contend,
and so the world will of itself be upright.

*Silk Manuscript Laozi, Collated—2,426 characters*

chunks.original_text: 上德不德，是以有德。 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为也。 上仁为之而无以为也。 上义为之而有以为也。 上礼为之而莫之应也。 则攘臂而乃之，故失道。 失道矣而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之泊也，而乱之首也。 前识者，道之华也，而愚之首也。 是以大丈夫居亓厚而不居亓泊。 居亓实而不居亓华。 故去皮取此。 昔之得一者，天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵，浴得一以盈，侯王得一而以为正。 亓致之也，胃天毋已清将恐莲，胃地毋已宁将恐发，胃神毋已灵将恐歇，胃浴毋已盈将恐渴，胃侯王毋已贵以高将恐厥。 故必贵而以贱为本，必高矣而以下为基。 夫是以侯王自胃孤寡不谷，此亓贱之本与，非也。 故致数与无与。 是故不欲禄禄若玉，硌硌若石。 上士闻道，堇能行之。 中士闻道，若存若亡。 下士闻道，大笑之。 弗笑，不足以为道。 是以建言有之曰：明道如费，进道如退，夷道如类； 上德如浴，大白如辱，广德如不足； 建德如揄，质真如愉，大方无禺，大器曼成，大音希声； 天象无刑，道褒无名。 夫唯道，善始且善成。 反也者，道之动也。 弱也者，道之用也。 天下之物生于有，有生于无。 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，中气以为和。 天下之所恶，唯孤寡不谷，而王公以自名也。 勿或损之而益，益之而损。 故人之所教，夕议而教人。 故强良者不得死，我将以为学父。 天下之至柔，驰骋于天下之致坚。 无有入于无间。 吾是以知无为之有益也。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希能及之矣。 名与身孰亲，身与货孰多，得与亡孰病。 甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 故知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 大成若缺，亓用不币。 大盈若中，亓用不穷。 大直如诎，大巧如拙，大赢如内。 躁胜寒，靓胜炅，请靓可以为天下正。 天下有道，却走马以粪。 天下无道，戎马生于郊。 罪莫大于可欲，祸莫大于不知足，咎莫惨于欲得。 故知足之足，恒足矣。 不出于户，以知天下。 不规于牖，以知天道。 亓出也弥远，亓知也弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，弗为而成。 为学者日益，闻道者日损。 损之又损，以至于无为。 无为而无不为也。 取天下也，恒无事。 及亓有事也，不足以取天下。 圣人无恒心，以百姓之心为心。 善者善之，不善者亦善之，德善也。 信者信之，不信者亦信之，德信也。 圣人之在天下，[翕心][翕心]焉，为天下浑心。 百姓皆属耳目焉，圣人皆咳之。 出生入死。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三，而民生生，动皆之死地之十有三。 夫何故也，以亓生生也。 盖闻善执生者，陵行不辟矢虎，入军不被甲兵。 矢无所揣亓角，虎无所昔亓蚤，兵无所容亓刃。 夫何故也，以亓无死地焉。 道生之而德畜之，物刑之而器成之。 是以万物尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵也。 夫莫之爵而恒自然也。 道生之，畜之，长之，遂之，亭之，毒之，养之，复之。 生而弗有也，为而弗寺也，长而勿宰也，此之胃玄德。 天下有始，以为天下母。 既得亓母，以知亓子。 复守亓母，没身不殆。 塞亓闷，闭亓门，终身不堇。 启亓闷，济亓事，终身不棘。 见小曰明，守柔曰强。
chunks.translated_text:
Higher virtue does not act as virtue, and thus possesses virtue.
Lower virtue does not lose virtue, and thus lacks virtue.
Higher virtue acts not and has no purpose in acting.
Higher benevolence acts but has no purpose in acting.
Higher righteousness acts and has purpose in acting.
Higher ritual acts, yet none respond—
then one rolls up sleeves and forces compliance.
Thus the Way is lost.

When the Way is lost, then comes virtue;
when virtue is lost, then comes benevolence;
when benevolence is lost, then comes righteousness;
when righteousness is lost, then comes ritual.
Ritual is the thinning of loyalty and trust,
the beginning of chaos.
Foreknowledge is the flower of the Way,
the beginning of folly.
Therefore the great man dwells in the thick, not in the thin;
in the solid, not in the flowery.
Thus he discards the latter and takes the former.

Of old, those who attained the One:
Heaven attained the One and became clear;
Earth attained the One and became tranquil;
spirits attained the One and became numinous;
valleys attained the One and became full;
lords and kings attained the One and became upright.
This is how they attained it.
If Heaven were not clear, it would fear to rend;
if Earth were not tranquil, it would fear to quake;
if spirits were not numinous, they would fear to vanish;
if valleys were not full, they would fear to dry;
if lords and kings were not noble and exalted, they would fear to fall.
Thus the noble must take the lowly as its root,
the high must take the low as its foundation.
Therefore lords and kings call themselves "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute"—
this is taking the lowly as their root, is it not?
Thus attaining the utmost in praise is to receive no praise.
Therefore do not desire to be jingling like jade,
nor clattering like stone.

The highest scholar, hearing the Way, diligently practices it.
The middling scholar, hearing the Way, sometimes keeps it, sometimes loses it.
The lowest scholar, hearing the Way, laughs loudly at it.
If it were not laughed at, it would not be the Way.
Thus the established sayings have it:
The bright Way seems dim;
the advancing Way seems to retreat;
the level Way seems uneven.
Higher virtue seems like a valley;
great whiteness seems sullied;
abundant virtue seems insufficient.
Established virtue seems unsteady;
true substance seems fickle;
the great square has no corners;
the great vessel is slow to form;
the great tone has scarce sound.
The heavenly image has no form;
the Way, though vast, has no name.
Only the Way is good at beginning and good at completing.

Reversion is the movement of the Way;
weakness is the function of the Way.
The myriad things of the world are born of being;
being is born of non-being.

The Way generates the One,
the One generates the Two,
the Two generate the Three,
the Three generate the myriad things.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
blending their qi to attain harmony.

What the world despises—
"orphaned," "widowed," "destitute"—
are the very names kings and dukes use for themselves.
Thus things may be diminished yet increased,
or increased yet diminished.
What others teach, I also teach:
"The violent do not die a natural death."
I shall take this as the father of my teaching.

The softest under heaven
gallops through the hardest under heaven.
Non-being enters where there is no gap.
Thus I know the benefit of non-action.
Teaching without words,
the benefit of non-action—
few under heaven can attain this.

Which is dearer, fame or life?
Which is greater, life or wealth?
Which is more harmful, gain or loss?
Excessive love must lead to great expenditure;
hoarding much must lead to heavy loss.
Thus, knowing contentment brings no disgrace;
knowing when to stop brings no danger—
this is how to endure long.

Great perfection seems flawed,
yet its use is never exhausted.
Great fullness seems empty,
yet its use is never depleted.
Great straightness seems bent;
great skill seems clumsy;
great eloquence seems halting.

Restlessness overcomes cold;
stillness overcomes heat.
Purity and stillness can set the world right.

When the world has the Way,
warhorses are retired to fertilize fields.
When the world lacks the Way,
cavalry mounts are born in the wilds.
No sin is greater than desire;
no calamity is greater than discontent;
no fault is more grievous than covetousness.
Thus, knowing contentment’s contentment
is always contentment.

Without stepping outside, know the world;
without looking out the window, know the heavenly Way.
The farther one goes,
the less one knows.
Thus the sage knows without traveling,
names without seeing,
accomplishes without acting.

Those who pursue learning increase day by day;
those who hear the Way decrease day by day.
Decrease and further decrease,
until one reaches non-action.
Through non-action, nothing is left undone.
To take the world, one must always be without affairs.
If one engages in affairs,
one is not fit to take the world.

The sage has no fixed mind,
but takes the people’s mind as his mind.
The good, he treats as good;
the not-good, he also treats as good—
thus attaining goodness.
The trustworthy, he trusts;
the untrustworthy, he also trusts—
thus attaining trustworthiness.
The sage, in the world,
contracts his mind for the world,
blending his mind with the world.
The people all strain their ears and eyes,
and the sage treats them all as children.

Emerging into life, entering death.
Those who follow life are thirteen;
those who follow death are thirteen;
yet people, in living their lives,
all move toward the land of death—thirteen.
Why is this?
Because they cling to life too tightly.
I have heard that one who is good at preserving life
walks the hills without avoiding rhinos or tigers,
enters battle without donning armor or weapons.
The rhino has nowhere to thrust its horn;
the tiger has nowhere to sink its claws;
weapons have nowhere to lodge their blades.
Why is this?
Because there is no place of death in him.

The Way gives them life, and virtue rears them;
things shape them, and instruments complete them.
Thus the myriad things honor the Way and value virtue.
The honor of the Way, the value of virtue—
nothing bestows this, yet it is always natural.
The Way gives them life, rears them,
nurtures them, matures them,
ripens them, sustains them,
protects them, and returns them.
Giving life without possessing,
acting without claiming,
leading without dominating—
this is called profound virtue.

The world has a beginning,
which may be taken as the mother of the world.
Having attained the mother,
one may know her children.
Having known the children,
return to guard the mother—
and to the end of life, one will not be imperiled.
Block the openings,
shut the doors—
and to the end of life, one will not be weary.
Open the openings,
multiply affairs—
and to the end of life, one will not be saved.
Seeing the small is called illumination;
guarding the soft is called strength.

soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.
Fish must not be removed from the depths.
A state’s sharpest instruments must not be displayed.

The Dao is ever nameless.
If lords and kings could hold to it,
the myriad things would transform of themselves.
Should desire arise,
I shall press it down
with the uncarved block of nameless simplicity.
The uncarved block of nameless simplicity
will not contend,
and so the world will of itself be upright.

chunks.original_text: 用亓光，复归亓明。 毋道身央，是胃袭常。 使我介有知也，行于大道。 唯他是畏，大道甚夷，民甚好解。 朝甚除，田甚芜，仓甚虚，服文采，带利剑，厌食，货财有余，是胃盗竽。 盗竽，非道也。 善建者不拔，善抱者不脱。 子孙以祭祀不绝。 修之身亓德乃真，修之家亓德有余，修之乡亓德乃长，修之邦亓德乃丰，修之天下亓德乃博。 以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以邦观邦，以天下观天下。 吾何以知天下之然兹？ 以此。 含德之厚者，比于赤子。 逢刺畏地弗螫，攫鸟猛兽弗搏，骨弱筋柔而握固，未知牝牡之会而脧怒，精之至也。 终日号而不忧，和之至也。 和曰常，知和曰明，益生曰祥，心使气曰强。 物壮即老，胃之不道，不道蚤已。 知者弗言，言者弗知。 塞亓闷，闭亓门，和亓光，同亓尘，坐亓阅，解亓纷，是胃玄同。 故不可得而亲，亦不可得而疏。 不可得而利，亦不可得而害。 不可得而贵，亦不可得而浅。 故为天下贵。 以正之邦，以畸用兵，以无事取天下。 吾何以知亓然也哉？ 夫天下多忌讳，而民弥贫。 民多利器，而邦家兹昏。 人多知，而何物兹起。 法物兹章，而盗贼多有。 是以圣人之言曰：我无为也，而民自化； 我好静，而民自正； 我无事，而民自富； 我欲不欲，而民自[木屋]。 亓正闵闵，亓民屯屯。 亓正察察，亓邦夬夬。 祸，福之所倚； 福，祸之所伏。 孰知亓极？ 亓无正也，正复为畸，善复为妖。 人之迷也，亓日固久矣。 是以方而不割，兼而不刺，直而不绁，光而不眺。 治人事天莫若啬。 夫唯啬，是以蚤服。 蚤服是胃重积德。 重积德则无不克。 无不克则莫知亓极。
chunks.translated_text:
Use its light,
return to its clarity—
not letting the body come to harm,
this is called inheriting the constant.

Were I to have the slightest knowledge,
I would walk the great Way,
fearing only to stray.
The great Way is level,
yet the people delight in byways.

The court is immaculate,
the fields overgrown,
the granaries empty.
They wear fine brocades,
bear sharp swords,
surfeit on food and drink,
hoard wealth in excess—
these are called thieves and braggarts.
Thieves and braggarts are not of the Way.

What is well planted cannot be uprooted,
what is well embraced cannot slip away.
Through this, descendants’ sacrifices never cease.

Cultivate it in the self, and its virtue is genuine;
cultivate it in the household, and its virtue abounds;
cultivate it in the village, and its virtue endures;
cultivate it in the state, and its virtue flourishes;
cultivate it in the world, and its virtue is vast.

Observe the self through the self,
observe the household through the household,
observe the village through the village,
observe the state through the state,
observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

One whose virtue is deeply rooted
is like an infant:
wasps and scorpions do not sting,
wild beasts do not seize,
birds of prey do not strike.
Though bones are weak and sinews soft, the grasp is firm.
Not yet knowing the union of male and female, the organ stirs—
such is the perfection of essence.
Crying all day without hoarseness—
such is the perfection of harmony.
To know harmony is called the constant;
to know the constant is called illumination.
To augment life is called ill-omened;
for the mind to command qi is called force.
When things reach their prime, they age—
this is called not the Way.
What is not the Way ends early.

The wise do not speak,
those who speak are not wise.
Block the openings,
shut the doors,
blunt the sharpness,
untangle the knots,
soften the glare,
merge with the dust—
this is called profound unity.

Thus, it cannot be made close,
nor can it be made distant.
It cannot be benefited,
nor can it be harmed.
It cannot be exalted,
nor can it be debased.
Therefore, it is honored by the world.

Govern the state with uprightness,
use the army with surprise,
take the world with non-action.
How do I know this is so?
By this:

The more taboos in the world,
the poorer the people.
The more sharp tools the people have,
the more benighted the state.
The more knowledge people possess,
the more strange things arise.
The more laws and ordinances are displayed,
the more thieves and bandits appear.
Therefore, the sage says:
I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves;
I love stillness, and the people right themselves;
I do nothing, and the people enrich themselves;
I desire not to desire, and the people become simple as uncarved wood.

When the ruler is dim and dull,
the people are honest and simple.
When the ruler is keen and sharp,
the state is divided and perilous.
Disaster is where fortune leans;
fortune is where disaster lurks.
Who knows their limit?
There is no constant standard.
The upright turns to the strange,
the good turns to the ominous.
The people’s delusion has lasted long indeed.

Thus, the square is not cut,
the inclusive is not piercing,
the straight is not restrictive,
the bright is not dazzling.

In governing people and serving Heaven,
nothing surpasses frugality.
Only through frugality can one be early prepared.
Being early prepared is called accumulating virtue.
Accumulating virtue, there is nothing one cannot overcome.
Having nothing one cannot overcome,
none can know its limit.

chunks.original_text: 莫知亓极，可以有国。 有国之母，可以长久。 是胃深槿固氐，长生久视之道也。 治大国若亨小鲜。 以道立天下，亓鬼不神。 非亓鬼不神也，亓神不伤人也。 非亓申不伤人也，圣人亦弗伤也。 夫两不相伤，故德交归焉。 大邦者，下流也，天下之牝也，天下之郊也。 牝恒以靓胜牡。 为亓靓也，故宜为下。 大邦以下小邦，则取小邦。 小邦以下大邦，则取于大邦。 故或下以取，或下而取。 故大邦者不过欲兼畜人，小邦者不过欲入事人。 夫皆得亓欲，则大者宜为下。 道者，万物之注也。 善人之葆也，不善人之所葆也。 美言可以市，尊行可以贺人。 人之不善也，何弃也之有？ 故立天子，置三卿，虽有共之璧以先四马，不善坐而进此。 古之所以贵此道者，何也？ 不胃求以得，有罪以免舆。 故为天下贵。 为无为，事无事，味无未。 大小多少报怨以德。 图难乎亓易也，为大乎亓细也。 天下之难作于易，天下之大作于细。 是以圣人冬不为大，故能成亓大。 夫巠若必寡信，多易必多难。 是以圣人猷难之，故冬于无难。 亓安也，易持也。 亓未兆也，易谋也。 亓脆也，易判也。 亓微也，易散也。 为之于亓未有也，治之于亓未乱也。 合抱之木，生于毫末。 九成之台，作于羸土。 百仁之高，台于足下。 为之者败之，执之者失之。 是以圣人无为也，故无败也； 无执也，故无失也。 民之从事也，恒于亓成事而败之。 故慎终若始，则无败事矣。 是以圣人欲不欲而不贵难得之货，学不学而复众人之所过。 能辅万物之自然，而弗敢为。 故曰：为道者，非以明民也，将以愚之也。 民之难治也，以亓知也。 故以知知邦，邦之贼也。 以不知知邦，邦之德也。 恒知此两者，亦稽式也。 恒知稽式，此胃玄德。 玄德深矣远矣，与物反矣，乃至大顺。 江海所以能为百浴王者，以亓善下之，是以能为百浴王。 是以圣人之欲上民也，必以亓言下之。 亓欲先民也，必以亓身后之。 故居前而民弗害也，居上而民弗重也。 天下乐隼而弗厌也。 非以亓无诤与？ 故天下莫能与诤。 小邦颁民，使十百人之器毋用，使民重死而远送。 有车周无所乘之，有甲兵无所陈之。 使民复结绳而用之。 甘亓食，美亓服，乐亓俗，安亓居。 邻邦相望，鸡狗之声相闻，民至老死不相往来。 信言不美，美言不信。 知者不博，博者不知。 善者不多，多者不善。 圣人无积，既以为人已俞有，既以予人矣已俞多。 故天之道，利而不害。 人之道，为而弗诤。 天下皆胃我大，大而不宵。 夫唯大，故不宵。 若宵，细久矣。 我恒有三，葆之：一曰兹，二曰检，三曰不敢为天下先。 夫兹，故能勇。 检，故能广。 不敢为天下先，故能为成事长。 今舍亓兹且勇，舍亓后且先，则必死矣。 夫兹以战则胜，以守则固。 天将建之，女以兹垣之。 善为士者不武，善战者不怒，善胜敌者弗与，善用人者为之下。 是胃不诤之德，是胃用人，是胃天古之极也。 用兵有言曰：吾不敢为主而为客，吾不敢进寸而芮尺。 是胃行无行，襄无臂，执无兵，乃无敌矣。 祸莫大于无适，无适斤亡吾葆矣。 故称兵相若，则哀者胜矣。 吾言甚易知也，甚易行也，而人莫之能知也，莫之能行也。 言有君，事有宗，夫唯无知也，是以不我知。
chunks.translated_text:
Whose limit none can know—this is how one may possess the state.
Possessing the state’s mother, one may endure long.
This is called deep roots and firm foundation,
the Dao of long life and enduring vision.

Governing a great state is like cooking a small fish.
When the world is established by the Dao,
its ghosts do not become spirits.
Not that its ghosts do not become spirits,
but their spirits do not harm people.
Not that their spirits do not harm people,
but the sage also does not harm.
When the two do not harm each other,
virtue and power thus converge.

A great state is the lower reaches,
the female of the world,
the meeting place of the world.
The female always overcomes the male through stillness.
Being still, she thus fittingly remains below.
When a great state lowers itself to small states, it wins over small states.
When a small state lowers itself to a great state, it wins over the great state.
Thus, some lower themselves to win,
some lower themselves and win.
A great state desires nothing more than to unite and nurture people;
a small state desires nothing more than to enter and serve people.
When both attain their desires,
the greater must fittingly remain below.

The Dao is the wellspring of the ten thousand things.
It is the treasure of the good,
and the refuge of the not-good.
Fine words can be traded in the marketplace;
noble conduct can bring honor to others.
If people are not good,
why should they be cast aside?
Thus, when establishing the Son of Heaven
and appointing the Three Ministers,
though one may have jade discs preceded by teams of four horses,
it is better to sit and present this.

Why was this Dao esteemed by the ancients?
Is it not because one seeks and obtains,
and sins are thereby absolved?
Thus, it is honored throughout the world.

Practice non-action, engage in no business,
savor the flavorless.
Great or small, many or few—repay enmity with virtue.
Resolve difficulty in its ease,
achieve greatness in its smallness.
The world’s difficulties arise from ease;
the world’s greatness arises from smallness.
Therefore, the sage never strives for greatness,
and thus accomplishes greatness.

If one is hasty, trust will be scarce;
if one takes things lightly, difficulties will multiply.
Therefore, the sage treats difficulty with care,
and thus never encounters difficulty.

In its tranquility, it is easy to hold.
In its unformed state, it is easy to plan.
In its fragility, it is easy to break.
In its subtlety, it is easy to scatter.
Act before it exists;
govern before it becomes chaotic.

A tree of arm-spanning girth grows from a tiny sprout.
A nine-tiered terrace rises from a basket of earth.
A journey of a hundred *ren* begins beneath one’s feet.
Those who act will fail;
those who grasp will lose.
Thus, the sage practices non-action and does not fail,
holds nothing and does not lose.

In their undertakings, people often fail when near completion.
Therefore, be as cautious at the end as at the beginning,
and there will be no failure.

Thus, the sage desires what others do not desire
and does not prize rare goods.
He learns what others do not learn,
returning to what the multitude has passed by.
He can assist the natural course of the ten thousand things
but dares not act.

Therefore, it is said:
Those who follow the Dao do not enlighten the people,
but rather keep them simple.
The people are difficult to govern
because of their knowledge.
Thus, governing a state with knowledge
is the state’s ruin.
Governing a state without knowledge
is the state’s blessing.
To constantly know these two principles
is also a model.
To constantly know this model
is called profound virtue.
Profound virtue is deep and far-reaching,
turning back with things to reach great compliance.

The reason rivers and seas can be kings of all valleys
is because they excel at staying low.
Thus, they can be kings of all valleys.
Therefore, when the sage wishes to be above the people,
he must speak as though he is below them.
When he wishes to lead the people,
he must place himself behind them.
Thus, though he dwells in front, the people do not feel harmed;
though he dwells above, the people do not feel burdened.
The world delights in following him and does not grow weary.
Is it not because he does not contend?
Thus, none in the world can contend with him.

A small state with few people,
though it has tools for a hundred or a thousand,
does not use them.
It makes the people value life and not travel far.
Though there are boats and carriages, none ride them;
though there are armor and weapons, none display them.
It makes the people return to knotting cords for use.
They find their food sweet,
their clothing beautiful,
their customs joyful,
their dwellings secure.
Neighboring states are within sight,
the sounds of chickens and dogs are within hearing,
yet the people grow old and die without ever visiting one another.

Though true words are not beautiful,
beautiful words are not true.
The wise are not learned;
the learned are not wise.
The good are not excessive;
the excessive are not good.
The sage accumulates nothing.
Having fully given to others, he has even more;
having fully bestowed upon others, he has even greater abundance.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven benefits and does not harm.
The Dao of humans acts but does not contend.

The world all say I am great, great yet not confined.
It is precisely because I am great that I am not confined.
If I were confined, I would have long since become small.

I always have three treasures to preserve:
the first is compassion,
the second is frugality,
the third is not daring to be first in the world.
With compassion, one can be brave.
With frugality, one can be expansive.
Not daring to be first in the world,
one can become the leader of all things.

Now, if one abandons compassion yet seeks bravery,
abandons humility yet seeks precedence,
one will surely perish.
Compassion in battle brings victory;
in defense, it brings firmness.
Heaven will establish one—
you should surround them with compassion.

The good warrior is not martial;
the good fighter is not enraged;
the good conqueror does not engage the enemy;
the good employer of people remains below them.
This is called the virtue of non-contention,
the power of employing people,
the ultimate of Heaven’s ancient ways.

There is a saying in the use of arms:
I dare not be the host but act as the guest;
I dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot.
This is called marching without marching,
raising arms without arms,
wielding weapons without weapons,
facing no enemy.
No disaster is greater than underestimating the enemy;
underestimating the enemy risks losing my treasures.
Thus, when evenly matched armies clash,
the grieving side will prevail.

My words are very easy to know,
very easy to practice,
yet none in the world can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have an origin;
affairs have a master.
It is only through ignorance
that I am not known.

chunks.original_text: 知者希，则我贵矣。 是以圣人被褐而怀玉。 知不知，尚矣。 不知不知，病矣。 是以圣人之不病，以亓病病也，是以不病。 民之不畏畏，则大畏将至矣。 毋闸亓所居，毋厌亓所生。 夫唯弗厌，是以不厌。 是以圣人自知而不自见也，自爱而不自贵也。 故去被取此。 勇于敢者则杀，勇于不敢者则栝。 此两者或利或害，天之所恶，孰知亓故？ 天之道，不战而善胜，不言而善应，不召而自来，弹而善谋。 天罔[衣圣][衣圣]，疏而不失。 若民恒是不畏死，奈何以杀惧之也？ 若民恒是死，则而为者吾将得而杀之。 夫孰敢矣？ 若民恒是必畏死，则恒有司杀者。 夫伐司杀者杀。 是伐大匠斫也。 夫伐大匠斫者，则希不伤亓手矣。 人之饥也，以亓取食税之多也，是以饥。 百姓之不治也，以亓上有以为也，是以不治。 民之巠死，以亓求生之厚也，是以巠死。 夫唯无以生为者，是贤贵生。 人之生也柔弱，亓死也仞贤强。 万物草木之生也柔脆，亓死也枯槁。 故曰：坚强者，死之徒也； 柔弱微细，生之徒也。 兵强则不胜，木强则恒。 强大居下，柔弱微细居上。 天下之道，酉张弓者也。 高者印之，下者举之。 有余者损之，不足者补之。 故天之道损有余而益不足，人之道则不然损不足而奉有余。 孰能有余而有以取奉于天者乎？ 唯有道者。 是以圣人为而弗有，成功而不居也。 若此，其不欲见贤也。 天下莫柔弱于水，而攻坚强者莫之能胜也，以亓无以易之也。 水之胜刚也，弱之胜强也。 天下莫弗知也，而莫之能行也。 故圣人之言曰：受邦之诟，是胃社稷之主； 受邦之不祥，是胃天下之王。 正言若反。 和大怨，必有余怨，焉可以为善。 是以圣人右介，而不以责于人。 故有德司介，无德司[彻力]。 夫天道无亲，恒与善人。 道可道也，非恒道也。 名可名也，非恒名也。 无名，万物之始也。 有名，万物之母也。 故恒无欲也，以观其眇。 恒有欲也，以观其所噭。 两者同出，异名同胃。 玄之有玄，众眇之门。 天下皆知美为美，恶已。 皆知善，訾不善矣。 有无之相生也，难易之相成也，长短之相刑也，高下之相盈也，意声之相和也，先后之相隋也，恒也。 是以声人居无为之事，行不言之教，万物昔而弗始也，为而弗志也，成功而弗居也。 夫唯<弗>居，是以弗去。 不上贤，使民不争。 不贵难得之货，使民不为盗。 不见可欲，使民不乱。 是以声人之治也：虚其心，实其腹，弱其志，强其骨； 恒使民无知无欲也，使夫知不敢弗为而已，则无不治矣。 道中而用之，有弗盈也。 [氵肃]呵，始万物之宗。 锉其阅，解其纷，和其光，同其尘。 湛呵，始或存。 吾不知其谁子也，象帝之先。 天地不仁，以万物为刍狗。 声人不仁，以百省为刍狗。 天地之间，其猷橐龠舆，虚而不[氵屈]，动而俞出。 多闻数穷，不若守于中。 浴神不死，是胃玄牝。 玄牝之门，是胃天地之根。 绵绵呵，若存。 用之不堇。 天长地久，天地所以能长且久者，以其不自生也，故能长生。 是以声人芮其身而身先，外其身而身存。 不以其无私舆？ 故能成其私。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who know are rare—thus I am valued.
Therefore the sage wears coarse cloth while holding jade within.
To know yet not claim knowledge is supreme;
not to know yet claim knowledge is a flaw.
The sage is free from flaws
because he treats his flaw as a flaw—
thus he is free from flaws.

When the people no longer fear what should be feared,
great fear will come.
Do not restrict their dwelling,
do not stifle their livelihood.
Only by not stifling them will they not be stifled.
Thus the sage knows himself but does not display himself,
loves himself but does not exalt himself.
Therefore he discards the one and takes the other.

He who is brave in daring will be killed;
he who is brave in not daring will live.
Of these two, one brings benefit, the other harm.
What Heaven detests—who knows the reason?
The Dao of Heaven
does not contend yet excels in victory,
does not speak yet excels in response,
does not summon yet comes of itself,
is unhurried yet excels in planning.
Heaven’s net is vast,
wide-meshed yet nothing slips through.

If the people constantly do not fear death,
how can they be frightened with death?
If the people constantly fear death,
then those who act perversely I will seize and kill—
who would dare?
If the people must always fear death,
there is always an executioner.
To kill the executioner is like hewing the master carpenter’s wood—
few will not wound their own hands.

People suffer hunger
because their rulers take too much in taxes—
thus they suffer hunger.
The common people are ungovernable
because their superiors impose too many measures—
thus they are ungovernable.
The people disregard death
because they seek life too fervently—
thus they disregard death.
Only he who does not make life his purpose
is wiser than one who values life.

In life, people are supple and weak;
in death, they are stiff and strong.
All things—plants and trees—
in life are supple and fragile;
in death, they are withered and dry.
Thus it is said:
The stiff and strong are companions of death;
the supple, weak, and delicate are companions of life.
Therefore a strong army will not prevail,
a strong tree will be felled.
The great and strong dwell below;
the supple, weak, and delicate dwell above.

The Dao of Heaven is like drawing a bow:
the high is pressed down, the low is lifted up.
What has excess is reduced,
what is deficient is supplemented.
Thus the Dao of Heaven reduces excess and supplements deficiency,
but the human way is not so—
it reduces deficiency to serve excess.
Who can take from excess to offer to Heaven?
Only one who possesses the Dao.
Thus the sage acts but does not possess,
accomplishes but does not dwell.
In this way, he does not wish to display his worth.

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing can surpass it in overcoming the hard and strong—
nothing can replace it.
That the weak overcomes the strong,
the soft overcomes the hard—
none in the world do not know this,
yet none can practice it.
Thus the sage’s words say:
To bear the state’s disgrace is called master of the altars of soil and grain;
to bear the state’s misfortune is called king of all under Heaven.
True words seem paradoxical.

To reconcile great resentment,
some resentment will remain—
how can this be good?
Thus the sage holds the tally
but does not demand from others.
Therefore the virtuous control the tally,
the unvirtuous control the tax.
The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality—
it always sides with the good.

The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao.
The name that can be named is not the eternal name.
The nameless is the beginning of the ten thousand things;
the named is the mother of the ten thousand things.
Thus, in constant non-desire,
one observes its mystery;
in constant desire,
one observes its manifestations.
These two emerge together but differ in name.
Together they are called the profound.
Profound and more profound—
the gate of all mysteries.

When all under Heaven know beauty as beauty,
ugliness arises.
When all know good,
then non-good is established.
Thus being and non-being produce each other,
difficult and easy complete each other,
long and short shape each other,
high and low fill each other,
note and voice harmonize with each other,
before and after follow each other—
this is constant.

Therefore the sage dwells in non-action,
practices wordless teaching,
lets the ten thousand things arise without beginning them,
acts without claiming,
accomplishes without dwelling.
Only by not dwelling
does it not depart.

Do not exalt the worthy,
and the people will not contend.
Do not value rare goods,
and the people will not steal.
Do not display what is desirable,
and the people’s hearts will not be disturbed.
Thus the sage’s governance:
empties their minds,
fills their bellies,
weakens their ambitions,
strengthens their bones.
Always keeps the people without knowledge, without desire,
so that the knowledgeable dare not act—
then nothing will be ungoverned.

Apply the Dao in the center and use it without exhausting it.
Vast and deep—it is the ancestor of the ten thousand things.
Blunt its sharpness,
untangle its knots,
soften its glare,
merge with its dust.
Profound and still—it seems to endure.
I do not know whose child it is—
it seems to have existed before the Lord.

Heaven and Earth are not humane—
they treat the ten thousand things as straw dogs.
The sage is not humane—
he treats the hundred clans as straw dogs.
Between Heaven and Earth,
it is like a bellows—
empty yet inexhaustible,
moving and producing more.
Much talk leads to exhaustion—
better to guard the center.

The spirit of the valley never dies—
this is called the mysterious female.
The gate of the mysterious female
is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
Subtle and continuous—
it seems to exist.
Use it without effort.

Heaven is eternal, Earth enduring.
Heaven and Earth can be eternal and enduring
because they do not live for themselves—
thus they can live long.
Therefore the sage places himself behind yet finds himself ahead,
puts himself outside yet remains preserved.
Is it not because he is selfless?
Thus he can achieve his self.

The softest in the world
rides over the hardest in the world.
The insubstantial enters where there is no space.
Thus I know the benefit of non-action.
Wordless teaching,
the benefit of non-action—
few in the world attain these.

led marching without marching,
raising arms without arms,
wielding weapons without weapons,
facing no enemy.
No disaster is greater than underestimating the enemy;
underestimating the enemy risks losing my treasures.
Thus, when evenly matched armies clash,
the grieving side will prevail.

My words are very easy to know,
very easy to practice,
yet none in the world can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have an origin;
affairs have a master.
It is only through ignorance
that I am not known.

chunks.original_text: 上善治水，水善利万物而有静。 居众人之所恶，故几于道矣。 居善地，心善[氵肃]，予善信，正善治，事善能，动善时。 夫唯不静，故无尤。 [扌直]而盈之，不若其已。 [扌短]而沿之，不可长葆之。 金玉盈室，莫之守也。 贵富而骄，自遗咎也。 功述身芮，天之道也。 戴营[示白]抱一，能毋离乎。 [木专]气至柔，能婴儿乎。 修除玄蓝，能毋疵乎。 爱民栝邦，能毋以知乎。 天门启阖，能为雌乎。 明白四达，能毋以为乎。 生之，畜之，生而弗有也，长而弗宰也。 是胃玄德。 卅辐同一毂，当其无有，车之用也。 然埴为器，当其无有，埴器之用也。 凿户牖，当其无有，室之用也。 故有之以为利，无之以为用。 五色使人目明，驰骋田腊使人心发狂，难得之货使人之行方，五味使人之口[口相]，五音使人之耳聋。 是以声人之治也，为腹不为目。 故去罢耳此。 龙辱若惊，贵大[木完]若身。 苛胃龙辱若惊？ 龙之为下，得之若惊，失之若惊，是胃龙辱若惊。 何胃贵大[木完]若身？ 吾所以有大[木完]者，为吾有身也，及吾无身，有何[木完]？ 故贵为身于为天下，若可以[之石]天下矣。 爱以身为天下，女可以寄天下。 视之而弗见，名之曰[微耳]。 听之而弗闻，名之曰希。 抚之而弗得，名之曰夷。 三者不可至计，故混而为一。 一者，其上不[亻收]，其下不忽。 寻寻呵不可名也，复归于无物。 是胃无状之状，无物之象。 是胃忽望。 隋而不见其后，迎而不见其首。 执今之道，以御今之有，以知古始，是胃道纪。 古之善为道者，微眇玄达，深不可志。 夫唯不可志，故强为之容曰：与呵，其若冬涉水； 猷呵，其若畏四邻； 严呵，其若客； 涣呵，其若泽； 沌呵，其若[木屋]； [氵春]呵，其若浊； [氵庄]呵，其若浴。 浊而情之，余清。 女以重之，余生。 葆此道者，不欲盈。 夫唯不欲盈，是以能敝而不成。 至虚极也，守情表也。 万物旁作，吾以观其复也。 夫物云云，各复归于其根，曰情。 情，是胃复命。 复命，常也。 知常，明也。 不知常，[亡巾][亡巾]作凶。 知常容，容乃公，公乃王，王乃天，天乃道，道乃久。 [氵勿]身不[以心]。 大上，下知有之。 其次，亲誉之。 其次，畏之。 其下，母之。 信不足，案有不信。 猷呵，其贵言也。 成功遂事，而百省胃我自然。 故大道废，案有仁义。 知快出，案有大伪。 六亲不和，案有畜兹。 邦家[问心]乳，案有贞臣。 绝声弃知，民利百负。 绝仁弃义，民复畜兹。 绝巧弃利，盗贼无有。 此三言也，以为文未足，故令之有所属：见素抱[木屋]，少私而寡欲。 绝学无忧，唯与诃，其相去几何？ 美与恶，其相去何若？ 人之所畏，亦不可以不畏人。 望呵，其未央才。 众人熙熙，若乡于大牢，而春登台。 我泊焉未兆，若婴儿未咳。 累呵，如无所归。 众人皆有余，我独遗。 我禺人之心也，[春心][春心]呵。 鬻人昭昭，我独若[问月]呵。 鬻人蔡蔡，我独[问心][问心]呵。 忽呵，其若海。 望呵，其若无所止。 众人皆有以，我独门元以悝。 吾欲独异于人，而贵食母。 孔德之容，唯道是从。 道之物，唯望唯忽。 忽呵望呵，中有象呵。 望呵忽呵，中有物呵。
chunks.translated_text:
The highest virtue is like water—
water benefits the myriad things yet remains still.
It dwells where the multitude shuns,
thus it is near the Dao.

Dwell in a good place,
the heart in profound stillness,
give with good faith,
govern with good order,
act with good skill,
move with good timing.
Only by not contending
does one avoid blame.

To fill it when straight
is not as good as stopping.
To sharpen it to a point
cannot be preserved long.
A room filled with gold and jade
cannot be guarded.
Wealth and honor breed arrogance—
this brings one’s downfall.
To withdraw when the work is done
is the Dao of Heaven.

Nurture the luminous spirit, embrace the One—
can one not stray from it?
Concentrate the qi to utmost softness—
can one be like an infant?
Purify the profound mirror—
can one be without flaw?
Love the people and govern the state—
can one do so without cunning?
The gates of Heaven open and close—
can one remain the female?
Understanding all four directions—
can one do so without action?

Give life, nurture it—
give life yet do not possess,
act yet do not dominate.
This is called the mysterious virtue.

Thirty spokes share one hub—
where there is nothing, lies the use of the cart.
Clay is shaped into vessels—
where there is nothing, lies the use of the vessel.
Doors and windows are cut to make a room—
where there is nothing, lies the use of the room.
Thus, being is for benefit,
non-being is for use.

The five colors blind the eyes,
the chase of hunting maddens the heart,
rare goods corrupt conduct,
the five flavors dull the palate,
the five tones deafen the ears.
Thus the sage’s governance
is for the belly, not the eyes.
Therefore, discard the latter and take the former.

Favor and disgrace are like terror—
value great misfortune as one’s own body.
Why are favor and disgrace like terror?
Favor is lowly—
gaining it is like terror,
losing it is like terror.
This is why favor and disgrace are like terror.
Why value great misfortune as one’s own body?
The reason I have great misfortune
is because I have a self.
If I had no self,
what misfortune could there be?
Thus, one who values the self as the world
may be entrusted with the world.
One who loves the self as the world
may be given the world.

Look at it yet do not see—
call it the subtle.
Listen to it yet do not hear—
call it the rare.
Touch it yet do not grasp—
call it the elusive.
These three cannot be fully fathomed,
so they merge into one.
Its rising is not bright,
its falling is not dark.
Unceasing, unnameable—
it returns to nothingness.
This is the form of the formless,
the image of the imageless.
This is the elusive and evanescent.
Follow it and see no rear,
meet it and see no front.
Hold to the Dao of the present
to master the present’s being,
to know the ancient beginning.
This is the thread of the Dao.

The ancients who excelled in the Dao
were subtly profound and mysteriously penetrating,
so deep they could not be described.
Thus, forced to describe them, I say:
Yielding, as if crossing a winter stream;
cautious, as if fearing all around;
solemn, as if a guest;
dissolving, as if ice melting;
simple, as if uncarved wood;
turbid, as if muddy water;
vast, as if a valley.
Muddy water, when still, gradually clears.
Who can remain still
until the moment of action?
Those who preserve this Dao
do not desire fullness.
Only by not desiring fullness
can one remain worn yet not exhausted.

Attain utmost emptiness,
hold fast to profound stillness.
The myriad things arise together—
I observe their return.
Things flourish in abundance,
each returning to its root.
Returning to the root is called stillness.
Stillness is called returning to destiny.
Returning to destiny is the constant.
Knowing the constant is called illumination.
Not knowing the constant—
reckless action brings misfortune.
Knowing the constant brings acceptance,
acceptance brings impartiality,
impartiality brings kingship,
kingship brings Heaven,
Heaven brings the Dao,
the Dao brings enduringness.

Do not endanger the self.
In the highest,
the people know only that it exists.
Next,
they draw near and praise it.
Next,
they fear it.
Next,
they revile it.
When trust is insufficient,
there is indeed distrust.
Cautious, how precious are words!
When success is achieved and affairs completed,
the people say, “We are naturally so.”
Thus, when the great Dao is abandoned,
there is benevolence and righteousness.
When cleverness emerges,
there is great hypocrisy.
When the six relations are not in harmony,
there are filial piety and kindness.
When the state is in chaos,
there are loyal ministers.

Cut off sageliness, discard wisdom—
the people will benefit a hundredfold.
Cut off benevolence, discard righteousness—
the people will return to filial piety and kindness.
Cut off skill, discard profit—
there will be no thieves or robbers.
These three sayings,
as teachings, are insufficient.
Thus, let them have something to belong to:
manifest plainness, embrace simplicity,
reduce selfishness, diminish desires.

Abandon learning, and there will be no sorrow.
Between “yes” and “ah”—
how much difference is there?
Between beauty and ugliness—
how much difference is there?
What others fear,
one cannot but also fear.
Vast, it seems endless.
The multitude are joyous,
as if partaking in a great sacrifice,
as if ascending a terrace in spring.
I alone am tranquil, without sign,
like an infant who has not yet smiled.
Weary, as if with nowhere to return.
The multitude all have more than enough,
I alone seem lacking.
I have the heart of a fool—
so muddled, so confused!
The common people are bright,
I alone am dim.
The common people are sharp,
I alone am dull.
Vast, like the sea,
boundless, as if without end.
The multitude all have purpose,
I alone am stubborn and uncouth.
I alone differ from others,
and value being nourished by the Mother.

The appearance of great virtue
follows only the Dao.
The thing of the Dao
is elusive and evanescent.
Evanescent, elusive—
within it are images.
Elusive, evanescent—
within it are things.
Profound, obscure—
within it is essence.
Its essence is most real—
within it is trust.
From ancient times to the present,
its name does not depart,
through which we observe the beginning of all things.
How do I know the beginning of all things?
Through this.

the benefit of non-action—
